Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a new device for the treatment of periodontal disease. The device is a mini-invasive approach that uses a laser to remove plaque and bacteria from the gums. The study will compare the efficacy of the new device to the standard of care, which is scaling and root planing.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Periodontal disease is a common condition that affects the gums and bones that support the teeth. It is caused by the buildup of plaque and bacteria on the teeth and gums. If left untreated, periodontal disease can lead to tooth loss and other health problems. Scaling and root planing is the standard of care for treating periodontal disease. It involves removing plaque and bacteria from the teeth and gums. However, this procedure can be painful and time-consuming. The new device being studied in this study is a mini-invasive approach that uses a laser to remove plaque and bacteria from the gums. The study will compare the efficacy of the new device to the standard of care.

A Randomized Controlled Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy of a New Device for the Treatment of Periodontal Disease

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of this study was to examine the effects of a parenting program on parental stress, parental adjustment, and child behavior problems in a sample of parents of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Methods: A randomized controlled trial was conducted with 60 parents of children with ASD. The intervention group received a 9‐week parenting program, while the control group received no intervention. The primary outcome measures were parental stress and parental adjustment, and the secondary outcome measure was child behavior problems. Results: The intervention group showed significant improvements in parental stress and parental adjustment compared to the control group. The intervention group also showed significant improvements in child behavior problems compared to the control group. Conclusion: The findings suggest that the parenting program was effective in reducing parental stress and improving parental adjustment and child behavior problems in parents of children with ASD.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a parenting intervention program for parents of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The intervention program is designed to improve parenting skills and reduce parental stress. The study will compare the intervention group to a control group that receives no intervention. The study will also evaluate the impact of the intervention program on the child's behavior and development.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a developmental disorder that affects social communication and behavior. It is a lifelong condition that can have a significant impact on the child's development and the family's well-being. Parents of children with ASD often experience high levels of stress and may struggle with parenting skills. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a parenting intervention program for parents of children with ASD. The intervention program is designed to improve parenting skills and reduce parental stress. The study will compare the intervention group to a control group that receives no intervention. The study will also evaluate the impact of the intervention program on the child's behavior and development. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, the intervention group will receive the parenting intervention program, which consists of 10 weekly sessions. The intervention program will be delivered by a trained therapist and will focus on teaching parents effective parenting skills, such as positive reinforcement and behavior management techniques. The control group will not receive any intervention during this phase. In the second phase, both groups will receive the intervention program. The intervention program will be delivered to the control group, and the intervention group will receive a booster session. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention program. The primary outcome measure will be parental stress, which will be assessed using the Parenting Stress Index. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a web-based parenting intervention for parents of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and their typically developing (TD) siblings. The intervention, called SIBTime, is designed to improve the quality of the child-parent relationship and reduce parental stress. The study will compare the effectiveness of the intervention to a waitlist control group.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be a randomized controlled trial with two arms: an intervention group and a waitlist control group. The intervention group will receive the SIBTime intervention, which consists of a web-based parenting program and a mobile app for TD siblings. The waitlist control group will receive the intervention after the study is completed. The study will be conducted over a period of 21 months. The primary outcome measure will be the quality of the child-parent relationship, assessed using the Child-Parent Relationship Scale - Short Form. Secondary outcome measures will include parental stress, self-efficacy for parenting tasks, and the frequency of parents' engagement in the parenting practices targeted by the intervention. The study will also assess the system usability of the SIBTime app and parents' satisfaction with the intervention. Demographic information will be collected at baseline to characterize the sample. The commercial feasibility of the program will be assessed at Month 21.

A Randomized Controlled Trial of a Web-Based Parenting Intervention for Parents of Children With Autism Spectrum Disorder and Their Typically Developing Siblings

Autism Spectrum Disorder

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of dupilumab in participants with eosinophilic gastritis (EG) and eosinophilic duodenitis (ED) with or without eosinophilic gastroenteritis (EGID).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2/3, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of dupilumab in participants with EG and ED with or without EGID. Participants will be randomized to receive either dupilumab or placebo for 24 weeks. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the efficacy of dupilumab in reducing gastric eosinophil counts in participants with EG and ED with or without EGID. The secondary objectives of the study are to evaluate the efficacy of dupilumab in reducing duodenal eosinophil counts in participants with EG and ED with or without EGID, and to evaluate the safety and tolerability of dupilumab in participants with EG and ED with or without EGID.

Abstract:
Background: The combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab has shown promising antitumor activity in patients with non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and MET exon 14 skipping mutations. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this combination in patients with NSCLC and MET exon 14 skipping mutations. Methods: This is a phase Ib/II, open‐label, multicenter study. In Part A, the dose of Tepotinib will be escalated to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) or recommended phase II dose (RP2D) in combination with Pembrolizumab. In Part B, the RP2D will be evaluated in patients with NSCLC and MET exon 14 skipping mutations. The primary endpoint is the overall response rate (ORR) as defined by disease response using iRECIST. Secondary endpoints include progression‐free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), duration of response (DOR), and safety. Results: As of 15 December 2022, 19 patients have been enrolled in Part A, and the MTD/RP2D has been determined to be 500 mg/day. In Part B, 13 patients have been enrolled, and the ORR is 69.2% (95% CI: 35.8‐92.6%). The median PFS and OS are 10.3 months (95% CI: 4.1‐16.5 months) and not reached (95% CI: 10.3 months‐not reached), respectively. The most common treatment‐related adverse events (TRAEs) are rash (57.9%), diarrhea (52.6%), and fatigue (47.4%). Conclusions: The combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab is well tolerated and shows promising antitumor activity in patients with NSCLC and MET exon 1

Abstract:
Background: The combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab has shown promising antitumor activity in patients with non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) harboring MET exon 14 skipping mutations. This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Tepotinib in combination with Pembrolizumab in patients with advanced NSCLC. Methods: This is a multicenter, open‐label, phase Ib study. Patients with advanced NSCLC harboring MET exon 14 skipping mutations will be enrolled. Tepotinib will be administered orally at a dose of 500 mg once daily on a 21‐day cycle. Pembrolizumab will be administered intravenously at a dose of 200 mg every 3 weeks. The primary objective is to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of Tepotinib in combination with Pembrolizumab. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy. The exploratory objectives are to evaluate the pharmacokinetics (PK) of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab, and to explore the biomarkers associated with the response to the combination therapy. Results: As of December 2020, 13 patients have been enrolled in the study. The median age of the patients is 62 years (range, 42‐76 years), and 77% of the patients are male. The most common histological type is adenocarcinoma (85%). The most common MET exon 14 skipping mutation is 4‐base pair deletion (62%). The most common grade 3/4 adverse events are anemia (23%), hypertension (15%), and hypothyroidism (15%). The most common grade 3/4 laboratory abnormalities are anemia

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of a new treatment for patients with bladder pain syndrome/interstitial cystitis (BPS/IC). The treatment involves the use of a device that delivers low-level electrical stimulation to the bladder. The study will enroll 100 patients with BPS/IC who will be randomly assigned to receive either the active treatment or a sham treatment. The active treatment will be delivered for 30 minutes once a week for 6 weeks. The sham treatment will be delivered for 30 minutes once a week for 6 weeks, but the device will not be turned on. Both the active and sham treatments will be delivered using a small, handheld device that is placed on the lower abdomen. Patients will be asked to complete questionnaires and undergo physical examinations at the beginning of the study and at the end of the 6-week treatment period.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Bladder pain syndrome/interstitial cystitis (BPS/IC) is a chronic condition that affects millions of people worldwide. It is characterized by pelvic pain, urinary urgency, and urinary frequency. Current treatments for BPS/IC are limited and often ineffective. The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of a new treatment for patients with BPS/IC. The treatment involves the use of a device that delivers low-level electrical stimulation to the bladder. The study will enroll 100 patients with BPS/IC who will be randomly assigned to receive either the active treatment or a sham treatment. The active treatment will be delivered for 30 minutes once a week for 6 weeks. The sham treatment will be delivered for 30 minutes once a week for 6 weeks, but the device will not be turned on. Both the active and sham treatments will be delivered using a small, handheld device that is placed on the lower abdomen. Patients will be asked to complete questionnaires and undergo physical examinations at the beginning of the study and at the end of the 6-week treatment

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic low back pain. Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with chronic low back pain. The patients were randomly divided into two groups: the exercise group and the control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) and the Short Form‐36 (SF‐36) questionnaire at baseline and after the intervention. Results: There was a significant improvement in the quality of life of the patients in the exercise group compared to the control group, as measured by the ODI and SF‐36 questionnaires. Conclusion: A 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with chronic low back pain.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a new device, the T-Cath, in the treatment of patients with chronic total occlusion (CTO) of the coronary arteries. The T-Cath is a novel device that uses a combination of laser and balloon technology to open blocked arteries. The study will compare the T-Cath to standard treatment methods, such as balloon angioplasty and stenting, in terms of safety and effectiveness.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The T-Cath is a novel device that uses a combination of laser and balloon technology to open blocked arteries. The study will compare the T-Cath to standard treatment methods, such as balloon angioplasty and stenting, in terms of safety and effectiveness. The study will enroll patients with CTO of the coronary arteries who are candidates for revascularization. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either the T-Cath or standard treatment. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of successful revascularization, defined as the ability to open the blocked artery and restore blood flow to the heart muscle. Secondary outcome measures will include the rate of major adverse cardiac events (MACE), such as death, heart attack, and stroke, as well as the rate of procedural complications.

Abstract:
Background: The incidence of treatment‐related adverse events (AEs) is an important measure in clinical trials. However, it is often difficult to distinguish between AEs that are related to the treatment and those that are not. This study aimed to develop a method for estimating the incidence of treatment‐related AEs using a Bayesian hierarchical model. Methods: We used data from a randomized controlled trial of a new drug for the treatment of hypertension. The trial included 1,000 participants who were randomly assigned to receive either the new drug or a placebo. The primary outcome was the incidence of treatment‐related AEs, defined as any AE that was considered to be related to the study drug. We used a Bayesian hierarchical model to estimate the incidence of treatment‐related AEs, assuming that the incidence of AEs in the placebo group was known. Results: The incidence of treatment‐related AEs in the new drug group was estimated to be 10% (95% credible interval: 8‐12%). The incidence of treatment‐related AEs in the placebo group was estimated to be 5% (95% credible interval: 3‐7%). Conclusion: The proposed method for estimating the incidence of treatment‐related AEs using a Bayesian hierarchical model is a useful tool for clinical trials.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of temperature packing care in improving the quality of life of colorectal cancer and gastric cancer patients with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) is a common side effect of chemotherapy drugs, especially in patients with colorectal cancer and gastric cancer. It can cause various symptoms such as numbness, tingling, pain, and weakness in the hands and feet. These symptoms can significantly affect the quality of life of patients, leading to reduced physical function, decreased ability to perform daily activities, and emotional distress. Temperature packing care is a non-pharmacological intervention that involves applying hot or cold compresses to the affected areas. It is believed to help alleviate the symptoms of CIPN by improving blood circulation, reducing inflammation, and promoting nerve regeneration. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, the investigators will conduct a pilot study to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the temperature packing care intervention. The investigators will recruit 10 patients with CIPN who are receiving chemotherapy for colorectal cancer or gastric cancer. The patients will be randomly assigned to receive either hot or cold compresses for 20 minutes, three times a day for 10 days. The investigators will assess the patients' symptoms using the EORTC QLQ-CIPN20 questionnaire before and after the intervention. In the second phase, the investig

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to either the exercise group or the control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the participants was 64.2 ± 7.2 years, and the mean SGRQ score was 49.1 ± 10.2 at baseline. After the intervention, the mean SGRQ score in the exercise group decreased to 38.2 ± 9.8, while it remained unchanged in the control group (48.9 ± 10.5). The difference in the mean SGRQ score between the two groups was statistically significant (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Brief Summary

-----------------
This is an explorative, open-label, randomised, 3-way cross-over study to assess the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, safety and tolerability, nicotine extraction, palatability, and subjective effects of nicotine pouches in daily nicotine users. The study will be conducted in 2 parts: Part 1: A screening visit (Visit 1) will be conducted within 28 days prior to the first study visit (Visit 2). At Visit 1, the subject will be screened for eligibility and undergo a physical examination, vital signs measurements, and laboratory tests. Part 2: The study will consist of 4 study visits (Visits 2 to 5). At Visit 2, the subject will be randomised to one of the 3 treatment sequences. At Visit 3, the subject will use Test product 1. At Visit 4, the subject will use Test product 2. At Visit 5, the subject will use the Comparator product. At each study visit, the subject will use the assigned product for 30 minutes. Blood samples will be collected at pre-defined timepoints for pharmacokinetic analysis. Subjective effects will be assessed using questionnaires and subjective ratings. Safety and tolerability will be assessed through adverse event reporting, vital signs measurements, and laboratory tests.

Excellent. Now, let's discuss the primary outcome measures for your study. Based on the information you've provided, there are several primary outcome measures. The first one is the AUC from timepoint 0 to infinity (AUCinf). This measure assesses the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to infinity. It will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Another primary outcome measure is the AUC from timepoint 0 to timepoint t (AUC0-t). This measure evaluates the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to a specific timepoint. Similar to the previous measure, it will be assessed at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Yes, there are a few more primary outcome measures we should consider. The AUC from timepoint 0 to 30 minutes (AUC0-30min) and AUC from timepoint 0 to 60 minutes (AUC0-60min) are important measures for assessing the early exposure and bioavailability of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Both Cmax and Tmax are important primary outcome measures. Cmax assesses the maximum plasma concentration of nicotine achieved after IP use, while Tmax measures the time it takes to reach the maximum plasma concentration. These measures provide insights into the rate of absorption and the peak exposure of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Certainly. The first secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted amount (mg/unit) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure helps evaluate the efficiency of nicotine delivery and the consistency of nicotine content in the pouches. It will be assessed at visits 2 to 4.

Another secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted fraction (%) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure provides information on the bioavailability and release characteristics of nicotine from the pouches. It will also be evaluated at visits 2 to 4.

Yes, there are a few more secondary outcome measures. We should assess the highest recorded increase (Emax) in pulse rate from baseline, which helps evaluate the acute physiological effects of nicotine on cardiovascular function. Additionally, we should measure the mean score for each palatability question 30 minutes after the start of IP use, which provides insights into taste, flavor, and overall user experience. We should also evaluate urge-to-use, product-liking, intent-to-use-again, and onset-of-effect after IP use to assess user satisfaction and behavioral responses. Finally, we should monitor the frequency, seriousness, and intensity of adverse events (AEs) to ensure participant safety throughout the study.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of manipulation combined with exercise for patients with coccydynia.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Coccydynia is a common condition that causes pain in the coccyx area. It is often caused by trauma, such as a fall or car accident, and can be very painful and debilitating. The pain can be severe enough to interfere with daily activities and quality of life. Manipulation is a common treatment for coccydynia, but there is limited evidence on its effectiveness. This study aims to determine the efficacy of manipulation combined with exercise for patients with coccydynia. The study will include 60 patients with coccydynia who will be randomly assigned to either the manipulation group or the exercise group. The manipulation group will receive manipulation treatment, while the exercise group will receive exercise therapy. Both groups will receive treatment for 6 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the change from baseline in pain levels. Secondary outcome measures will include the change from baseline in functional disability, quality of life, and patient satisfaction.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a new treatment for coccydynia. The treatment involves a combination of exercises and coccyx manipulation. The study will compare the effectiveness of this treatment to a control group that receives only exercises.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Coccydynia is a common condition that causes pain and discomfort in the coccyx area. It is often caused by trauma, such as a fall or car accident, or by prolonged sitting. The pain can be severe and can interfere with daily activities. Current treatments for coccydynia include pain medication, physical therapy, and surgery. However, these treatments are often ineffective or have significant side effects. The investigators have developed a new treatment for coccydynia that involves a combination of exercises and coccyx manipulation. The exercises are designed to strengthen the muscles around the coccyx and improve posture. The coccyx manipulation involves a gentle adjustment of the coccyx to improve its alignment. The investigators hypothesize that this treatment will be more effective than exercises alone in reducing pain and improving function in patients with coccydynia. The study will enroll 60 patients with coccydynia who will be randomly assigned to either the treatment group or the control group. The treatment group will receive the new treatment for 4 weeks, while the control group will receive only exercises. Both groups will be evaluated at baseline, 4 weeks, and 6 months. The primary outcome measure will be the change in pain intensity from baseline to 4 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in functional status, quality of life, and patient satisfaction. The investigators expect that the new treatment will be more effective than exercises alone in reducing pain and improving function in patients with coccydynia.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized Controlled Trial of a New Treatment for Coccydynia

Conditions

Coccydynia

* Other: Coccyx manipulation

The MHQoL-7D covers seven dimensions, including self-esteem, independence, mood, relationships, daily activities, physical health, and future. The total score can range from 0 to 21, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. The MHQoL visual analog scale measures the respondent's general psychological well-being on a scale from zero to ten. The MHQoL-7D will be assessed before TAU, before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a thorough assessment of changes in quality of life and overall well-being.

Based on the study's objectives, I suggest considering the Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Questionnaire (NPI-Q). It assesses various neuropsychiatric symptoms commonly observed in patients with serious mental illness, such as delusions, hallucinations, agitation, depression, and more. The questionnaire is completed by caregivers, providing valuable insight into the severity of symptoms and the emotional burden on the caregiver. Does this measure align with your study objectives?

Certainly! The NPI-Q was developed and validated in 2000 and translated into Dutch in 2002. It contains 12 domains that can be used to map neuropsychiatric symptoms. These domains include delusions, hallucinations, agitation/aggression, depression/dysphoria, fear, euphoria/elation, apathy/indifference, disinhibited behavior, irritability/lability, aimless repetitive behavior, night restlessness/sleep disorder, and appetite/eating behavior change. The questionnaire assesses the presence and severity of each symptom, as well as the emotional burden on the caregiver. It will be assessed before the start of treatment as usual (TAU), before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a comprehensive evaluation of changes in symptoms over time.

For the second outcome measure, I recommend considering the Brief Symptom Inventory (BSI). This comprehensive questionnaire assesses psychological and physical symptoms in patients. It covers various domains such as somatic complaints, cognitive problems, interpersonal sensitivity, and more. The BSI provides a detailed overview of the patient's symptoms and their severity. It is also sensitive to therapy influences, making it suitable for evaluating the impact of the CoMBI-SMI intervention. Does this measure align with your study objectives?

Absolutely! The BSI is a multidimensional complaints list that assesses the extent to which the patient has experienced psychological and/or physical symptoms during the past period. It consists of 53 items scored on a scale from 0 to 4. There are 9 subscales, including somatic complaints, cognitive problems, interpersonal sensitivity, depressed mood, fear, hostility, phobic fear, paranoid thoughts, and psychoticism. The BSI will be assessed before TAU, before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a thorough assessment of changes in symptoms and overall well-being.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a 12‐week exercise program in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and to determine the effect of the program on the quality of life, exercise capacity, and lung function. Methods: A total of 40 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either the exercise group (n = 20) or the control group (n = 20). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, which included aerobic and resistance training. The control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life, exercise capacity, and lung function were assessed at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The exercise group showed significant improvements in the quality of life, exercise capacity, and lung function compared to the control group. Conclusion: The 12‐week exercise program was effective in improving the quality of life, exercise capacity, and lung function in patients with COPD.

1. "Mean change in Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) BCVA from baseline": This measure assesses the change in visual acuity using the ETDRS chart. It will evaluate the mean change in BCVA from baseline at Week 4 and Week 12, providing insights into the impact of BBC1501 on visual acuity improvement or deterioration. The ETDRS chart is a standardized chart used to measure visual acuity in patients with retinal diseases. It consists of a series of letters that gradually decrease in size, and patients are asked to read the smallest letters they can see. The score is based on the number of letters correctly read, with higher scores indicating better visual acuity.

2. "Change in CNV size according to fluorescein angiogram": This measure evaluates the change in choroidal neovascularization (CNV) size using fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA). It assesses the impact of BBC1501 on the progression or regression of CNV lesions at Week 4 and Week 12. FFA is a diagnostic technique that uses a fluorescent dye to visualize the blood vessels in the retina. It helps to identify the presence and extent of CNV, which is a hallmark of nAMD.

SD-OCT is a non-invasive imaging technique that uses light waves to create cross-sectional images of the retina. It helps to measure the thickness of the retina and detect the presence of fluid accumulation, which is a common feature of nAMD.

Abstract:
Background: Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of phenylalanine (Phe). Individuals with PKU have a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which results in the accumulation of Phe in the blood. This can lead to cognitive impairment, behavioral problems, and other health issues. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of L‐phenylalanine (L‐Phe) supplementation on cognitive function in individuals with PKU. Methods: A randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled crossover trial was conducted. Twenty‐four individuals with PKU were randomly assigned to receive either L‐Phe or placebo for 2 weeks, followed by a 2‐week washout period, and then the other treatment for another 2 weeks. Cognitive function was assessed using a battery of tests, including the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale‐III, the Trail Making Test, and the Stroop Color‐Word Test. Blood samples were collected to measure Phe levels. Results: There were no significant differences in cognitive function between the L‐Phe and placebo groups. However, there was a significant decrease in Phe levels in the L‐Phe group compared to the placebo group. Conclusion: L‐Phe supplementation did not improve cognitive function in individuals with PKU. However, it did lower Phe levels, which may have a positive impact on long‐term health outcomes.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the participants was 64.3 ± 7.5 years, and the mean body mass index was 28.5 ± 4.1 kg/m2. There was no significant difference in the baseline SGRQ scores between the two groups. After the intervention, the SGRQ scores decreased significantly in the exercise group compared to the control group (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of L-phenylalanine supplementation on cognitive function in PKU carriers.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of the amino acid phenylalanine (Phe). Individuals with PKU have a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), which is responsible for converting Phe to tyrosine. As a result, Phe accumulates in the blood and can lead to serious health problems, including intellectual disability, seizures, and behavioral problems. PKU is typically diagnosed in infancy through newborn screening, and individuals with PKU are treated with a low-Phe diet to prevent the accumulation of Phe in the body. However, individuals who are carriers of the PKU gene (i.e., those who have one copy of the gene but do not have the disorder) may also experience some of the negative effects of high Phe levels. In particular, PKU carriers may have impaired cognitive function, including problems with attention, memory, and executive function. L-phenylalanine (L-Phe) is a form of Phe that is found in many foods, including meat, dairy products, and some grains. It is also used as a dietary supplement to improve athletic performance and cognitive function. However, the effects of L-Phe supplementation on cognitive function in PKU carriers are not well understood. PKU carriers are individuals who carry one copy of the gene for PKU but do not have the disorder themselves. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a mobile health (mHealth) prehabilitation programme delivered via the Asensei app in patients with oesophago-gastric cancer. The study will also assess the impact of the intervention on the physical and mental well-being of participants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, the feasibility of the intervention will be evaluated by assessing the recruitment of participants, adherence to the intervention, and compliance with the study guidelines. In the second phase, the impact of the intervention on the physical and mental well-being of participants will be assessed. The study will involve a total of 30 participants who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive the mHealth prehabilitation programme delivered via the Asensei app, while the control group will receive standard care. The intervention group will be asked to use the Asensei app for 12 weeks prior to surgical intervention. The control group will not receive any intervention. Both groups will be assessed at baseline, 6 weeks, and 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be recruitment, adherence, and compliance. The secondary outcome measures will be physical and mental well-being. The study will use a mixed-methods approach to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention. Qualitative interviews will be conducted with a subset of participants to gather their feedback on the intervention. The study will also use quantitative data to assess the impact of the intervention on the physical and mental well-being of participants.

Official Title
-----------------
Prehabilitation Via a Mobile Application in Oesophago-gastric Cancer: A Feasibility Study

Primary outcome measure
=================
The primary outcome measure is the change in the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part III score from baseline to 12 weeks. The UPDRS is a validated scale that assesses the severity of Parkinson's disease symptoms, including motor symptoms such as tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. The UPDRS Part III score ranges from 0 to 108, with higher scores indicating more severe symptoms.

Secondary outcome measures
=================
The secondary outcome measures are the change in the UPDRS Part II score, the change in the UPDRS Part IV score, the change in the Timed Up and Go test, and the change in the 6-minute walk test from baseline to 12 weeks. The UPDRS Part II score assesses non-motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as cognitive impairment and depression. The UPDRS Part IV score assesses activities of daily living, such as dressing, bathing, and eating. The Timed Up and Go test measures the time it takes to stand up from a chair, walk 3 meters, turn around, walk back to the chair, and sit down. The 6-minute walk test measures the distance walked in 6 minutes.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a virtual reality (VR) intervention on anxiety levels in patients undergoing dental avulsions under local anesthesia. Methods: A randomized controlled trial was conducted on 60 patients aged 18‐65 years who were scheduled for dental avulsions. Patients were randomly assigned to either the VR group or the control group. The VR group received a VR intervention using a head‐mounted display (HMD) during the dental procedure, while the control group received standard care. Anxiety levels were assessed using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory‐State (STAI‐YA) questionnaire, the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), and the Dental Anxiety Scale (DAS) before and during the procedure. Results: The VR group showed a significant reduction in anxiety levels compared to the control group, as measured by the STAI‐YA questionnaire (p < 0.001), the VAS (p < 0.001), and the DAS (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The use of VR during dental avulsions under local anesthesia can effectively reduce anxiety levels in patients.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of individualized high PEEP on postoperative pulmonary complications in patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgeries. Methods: This randomized controlled trial was conducted on 100 patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgeries. The patients were randomly assigned to two groups: the control group and the intervention group. The control group received standard PEEP, while the intervention group received individualized high PEEP. The primary outcome measure was postoperative pulmonary complications, which were assessed within 10 days after surgery. The secondary outcome measure was pulmonary function tests, which were conducted before surgery and 10 days after surgery. Results: The incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications was significantly lower in the intervention group compared to the control group (10% vs. 30%, p=0.01). The pulmonary function tests showed that the intervention group had significantly higher FVC, FEV1, FEV1%, and FVC% compared to the control group (p<0.05). Conclusion: Individualized high PEEP can reduce the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications in patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgeries. It can also improve lung function, as evidenced by the pulmonary function tests.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to either an exercise group or a control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the participants was 65.3 ± 7.1 years, and the mean body mass index was 27.8 ± 4.1 kg/m2. The exercise group showed a significant improvement in the total SGRQ score (p = 0.001), as well as in the symptoms, activity, and impact subscales (p < 0.001 for all). The control group showed no significant change in the SGRQ scores. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to either an exercise group or a control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the participants was 65.3 ± 7.1 years, and the mean SGRQ score was 45.1 ± 10.2 at baseline. After the intervention, the mean SGRQ score decreased by 10.2 ± 10.2 in the exercise group and by 2.1 ± 10.2 in the control group (p < 0.001). The mean difference in the SGRQ score between the two groups was 8.1 ± 10.2 (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic low back pain. Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with chronic low back pain. The patients were randomly divided into two groups: the exercise group and the control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) and the Roland‐Morris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 45.2 ± 10.2 years. There was no significant difference in the baseline characteristics between the two groups. After the intervention, the ODI and RMDQ scores were significantly lower in the exercise group compared to the control group (p < 0.05). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with chronic low back pain.

The study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of behavioral management techniques in reducing dental anxiety among Iraqi adult patients seeking private dental care.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of DWJ1464 in patients with chronic liver disease.

Detailed Description
-----------------

The quality of life was assessed using the Short Form‐36 (SF‐36) questionnaire at baseline and after the intervention. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of pain neuroscience education (PNE) in reducing pain and improving function in patients with chronic knee pain.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Chronic knee pain is a common problem that affects millions of people worldwide. It can significantly impact daily activities and quality of life. Pain neuroscience education (PNE) is a non-pharmacological intervention that aims to educate patients about the neurobiology of pain and how it can be managed. PNE has been shown to be effective in reducing pain and improving function in patients with chronic pain conditions. However, its effectiveness in patients with chronic knee pain is not well established. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of PNE in reducing pain and improving function in patients with chronic knee pain. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with two groups: an intervention group that will receive PNE and a control group that will receive standard care. The intervention group will receive six sessions of PNE over a period of six weeks. The control group will receive standard care, which may include physical therapy, medication, or other treatments. The primary outcome measure will be the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) pain score. The secondary outcome measures will include the WOMAC function score, the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), and the Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC). The study will enroll 60 patients with chronic knee pain. The study will be conducted at a single site in the United States.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP). Methods: A total of 100 patients with CLBP were randomly assigned to either an exercise group or a control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group received no intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the EuroQol‐5 Dimensions‐5 Levels (EQ‐5D‐5L) questionnaire at baseline and after 12 weeks. Results: The exercise group showed significant improvements in all dimensions of the EQ‐5D‐5L questionnaire compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that an exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with CLBP.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the combination of the anti-PD-1 antibody pembrolizumab and the anti-CTLA-4 antibody ipilimumab in patients with advanced melanoma.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a phase II, open-label, single-arm, multicenter study. Patients with advanced melanoma who have not received prior systemic therapy will be enrolled. Patients will receive pembrolizumab 200 mg intravenously every 3 weeks and ipilimumab 1 mg/kg intravenously every 6 weeks for a total of 4 doses. The primary endpoint is the objective response rate (ORR) according to RECIST v1.1. Secondary endpoints include progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), safety, and quality of life (QoL).

A Phase II Study of Pembrolizumab and Ipilimumab in Patients With Advanced Melanoma

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a 12-week, home-based, progressive resistance training (PRT) program in improving physical function and quality of life in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a chronic, progressive lung disease that is characterized by airflow limitation and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Physical inactivity is a common problem in patients with COPD, and it is associated with decreased physical function, increased symptoms, and reduced quality of life. Progressive resistance training (PRT) is a type of exercise that involves the use of weights or resistance bands to increase muscle strength and endurance. PRT has been shown to improve physical function and quality of life in patients with COPD. However, there is limited evidence on the effectiveness of PRT in patients with COPD who are not able to attend a supervised exercise program. The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a 12-week, home-based, progressive resistance training (PRT) program in improving physical function and quality of life in patients with COPD. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with two groups: an intervention group that will receive the PRT program and a control group that will receive usual care. The PRT program will consist of 12 weeks of supervised exercise training, followed by 12 weeks of home-based exercise training. The intervention group will receive a home exercise program that includes resistance training exercises for the upper and lower body, as well as aerobic exercise. The control group will receive usual care, which may include education about COPD and pulmonary rehabilitation. The primary outcome measure will be the 6-minute walk test (6MWT), which is a measure of physical function. Secondary outcome measures will include the COPD Assessment Test (CAT), the St. George's Resp

Background: The use of opioids for pain management has been associated with adverse effects such as nausea, vomiting, and constipation. N‐acetylcysteine (NAC) is a natural antioxidant that has been shown to reduce opioid‐induced side effects. However, the effectiveness of NAC in reducing opioid consumption in patients undergoing a hysterectomy is not well established. This study aims to evaluate the impact of NAC on opioid consumption in patients undergoing a hysterectomy. Methods: This is a randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled trial. Patients undergoing a hysterectomy will be randomized to receive either NAC or placebo. The primary outcome measure is opioid consumption in the first 72 hours post‐medication. Secondary outcome measures include pain scores, nausea, vomiting, and constipation. Results: The study is currently ongoing and the results will be presented at the conference. Conclusion: The results of this study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness of NAC in reducing opioid consumption in patients undergoing a hysterectomy.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic low back pain. Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with chronic low back pain. The patients were randomly divided into two groups: the exercise group and the control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the Short Form‐36 (SF‐36) questionnaire at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 45.2 ± 10.1 years. There was no significant difference in the quality of life scores between the two groups at baseline. After the intervention, the exercise group had significantly higher scores in the physical functioning, role physical, bodily pain, general health, and vitality subscales of the SF‐36 questionnaire compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with chronic low back pain.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of dupilumab in the treatment of dermal hypersensitivity reaction (DHR).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Dermal hypersensitivity reaction (DHR) is a rare and severe skin condition that can cause significant morbidity and mortality. Current treatment options are limited and often ineffective. Dupilumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the interleukin-4 receptor alpha (IL-4Rα) and has been shown to be effective in the treatment of atopic dermatitis and asthma. In this study, the investigators will evaluate the safety and efficacy of dupilumab in the treatment of DHR. The study will enroll 20 patients with DHR who will be randomized to receive either dupilumab or placebo for 16 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) score from baseline to week 16. Secondary outcome measures will include the change in the Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI) score, the change in the Investigator's Global Assessment (IGA) score, and the change in the Patient's Global Assessment (PGA) score. The investigators will also evaluate the safety and tolerability of dupilumab in this patient population.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase 2, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of Dupilumab in the Treatment of Dermal Hypersensitivity Reaction

Conditions

Dermal Hypersensitivity Reaction

Abstract:
Background: Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability worldwide. Physical activity is an important factor in the prevention and treatment of stroke. However, there is a lack of studies on the physical activity of stroke patients in Turkey. The aim of this study is to determine the level of physical activity of stroke patients and to determine the factors affecting it. Methods: This study was conducted as a cross‐sectional study. The study was conducted with 100 stroke patients who were admitted to the neurology clinic of a university hospital between January 2021 and January 2022. The data of the patients were collected using the demographic form, the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE), the Barthel Index (BI), the Modified Rankin Scale (mRS), the Stroke Impact Scale (SIS), and the International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ). The data were analyzed using the SPSS 22.0 program. Results: The mean age of the patients was 62.1±11.1 years, and 54% of the patients were male. The mean time since the stroke was 10.1±7.1 months. The mean MMSE score was 24.1±3.1, the mean BI score was 82.1±17.1, and the mean mRS score was 2.1±0.9. The mean SIS score was 82.1±17.1, and the mean IPAQ score was 10.1±10.1. There was a significant positive correlation between the IPAQ score and the MMSE score (r=0.382, p=0.001), the BI score (r=0.362, p=0.001), and the SIS score (r=0.342, p=0.001). Conclusion: The level of physical activity of stroke patients is low. The level of physical activity of stroke patients is positively correlated with cognitive function, functional independence, and quality of life.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study included 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not. The quality of life of the patients was evaluated using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) before and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 64.2 ± 7.1 years, and 33 (55%) were male. The mean SGRQ score was 48.1 ± 11.1 before the intervention and 40.2 ± 10.1 after the intervention in the exercise group, while it was 48.1 ± 11.1 before the intervention and 46.1 ± 10.1 after the intervention in the control group. The mean SGRQ score was significantly lower in the exercise group compared to the control group after the intervention (p = 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study included 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the participants was 64.2 ± 7.2 years, and the mean body mass index was 28.1 ± 4.1 kg/m2. There was no significant difference in the baseline characteristics between the two groups. After the intervention, the SGRQ score decreased significantly in the exercise group compared to the control group (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week exercise program in improving balance and fall risk in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic, inflammatory, and demyelinating disease of the central nervous system (CNS) that affects approximately 2.3 million people worldwide. The disease is characterized by a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, cognitive impairment, and gait and balance problems. Balance and gait problems are common in individuals with MS and can lead to falls, which can cause serious injuries and reduce quality of life. Exercise has been shown to improve balance and gait in individuals with MS, but the optimal type and duration of exercise program is not yet known. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week exercise program in improving balance and fall risk in individuals with MS. The study will include 30 participants with MS who will be randomly assigned to either an exercise group or a control group. The exercise group will participate in a supervised exercise program that includes balance and gait training, while the control group will not participate in any exercise program. Both groups will be assessed at baseline and at the end of the 12-week intervention period. The primary outcome measure will be the Berg Balance Scale (BBS), which is a validated measure of balance and fall risk. Secondary outcome measures will include the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, the 10-meter walk test, and the Functional Reach Test (FRT). The study will also assess the feasibility of the exercise program and the acceptability of the intervention to participants. The results of this study will provide important information on the efficacy of exercise in improving balance and fall risk in individuals with MS.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effect of a 12-Week Exercise Program on Balance and Fall Risk in Individuals With Multiple Sclerosis: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Conditions
-----------------
Multiple Sclerosis

Intervention / Treatment

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a 12-week exercise program in improving balance and fall risk in individuals with stroke.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a 12-week exercise program in improving balance and fall risk in individuals with stroke. The study will be conducted in two phases: a baseline phase and an intervention phase. During the baseline phase, participants will undergo a series of assessments to determine their baseline balance and fall risk. These assessments will include the Berg Balance Scale (BBS), the International Fall Effectiveness Scale (FES-I), the Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS), the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), and the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). Participants will also undergo a 6-minute walk test (6MWT) to assess their physical fitness. During the intervention phase, participants will be randomly assigned to either the exercise group or the control group. The exercise group will participate in a 12-week exercise program that includes balance and strength training exercises. The control group will not receive any intervention. Both groups will undergo the same assessments as in the baseline phase at the end of the intervention phase. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the BBS score from baseline to the end of the intervention phase. The secondary outcome measures will be the change in the FES-I score, the FSS score, the BDI score, the PSQI score, and the 6MWT distance.

Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week exercise program in improving balance and gait in patients with Parkinson's disease.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, the participants will be randomly assigned to either the exercise group or the control group. The exercise group will participate in a 12-week exercise program, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The study will be conducted in a single center, and the participants will be followed up for 12 weeks after the intervention.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week exercise program in improving the physical function and quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a chronic respiratory disease characterized by airflow limitation that is not fully reversible. It is a major public health problem worldwide, with a high prevalence and mortality rate. COPD is associated with a significant reduction in physical function and quality of life, and exercise training is an important treatment for improving these outcomes. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week exercise program in improving the physical function and quality of life of patients with COPD. The study will include 60 patients with COPD who will be randomly assigned to either an exercise group or a control group. The exercise group will participate in a supervised exercise program that includes aerobic and resistance training, while the control group will receive usual care. The primary outcome measure will be the 6-minute walk test, and the secondary outcome measures will include the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire, the COPD Assessment Test, and the Modified Medical Research Council Dyspnea Scale. The study will also assess the safety and tolerability of the exercise program.

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Now, let me summarize the outcome measures we have designed for your clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Physical Activity Scale for the Physically Disabled (PASIPD): This 13-item scale assesses activities of daily living, domestic activities, and professional duties over the last 7 days. The time frame for measuring the PASIPD is 7 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale: This scale consists of 43 items and assesses the individual's level of belief in the benefit of exercise. The time frame for measuring the Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale is 7 months.
- Berg Balance Scale (BBS): This 14-item scale evaluates balance and fall risk. It measures the patient's ability to maintain balance while performing static or various functional movements. The time frame for measuring the BBS is 7 months.
- International Fall Effectiveness Scale (FES-I): This scale assesses the self-confidence of individuals in daily activities and their fear of falling. The time frame for measuring the FES-I is 7 months.
- Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS): This scale assesses the fatigue status of individuals over the past week. Those with an FSS score of 4 or higher are considered tired. The time frame for measuring the FSS is 7 months.
- Beck Depression Inventory (BDI): This inventory measures the symptoms of depression. It consists of 21 items graded between 0 and 3 points. The time frame for measuring the BDI is 7 months.
- Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI): This scale assesses the quality of sleep and disturbances experienced by individuals over the past month. The time frame for measuring the PSQI is 7 months.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) and exosomes in the diagnosis of breast cancer. Methods: A total of 100 patients with breast cancer and 100 healthy controls were enrolled in the study. ctDNA and exosomes were isolated from the peripheral blood of the patients and controls. The diagnostic accuracy of ctDNA and exosomes was evaluated using receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis. Results: The area under the curve (AUC) of ctDNA for the diagnosis of breast cancer was 0.92, with a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 88%. The AUC of exosomes for the diagnosis of breast cancer was 0.90, with a sensitivity of 88% and a specificity of 86%. Conclusion: ctDNA and exosomes have high diagnostic accuracy for the diagnosis of breast cancer.

We have agreed on the following outcome measures: Primary outcome measure: Positive predictive value of ctDNA/Exosome for breast cancer recurrence Secondary outcome measure: Negative predictive value of ctDNA/Exosome for breast cancer recurrence Time frame: 60 months for both outcome measures.

Brief summary
=================
Acanthosis nigricans is a common skin condition characterized by dark, velvety patches on the skin. It is often associated with insulin resistance and obesity. Topical treatments, such as trichloroacetic acid and tretinoin, are commonly used to treat acanthosis nigricans. However, there is limited evidence on the efficacy of these treatments. This study aims to compare the efficacy of topical 15% trichloroacetic acid and 0.05% tretinoin in the treatment of acanthosis nigricans. The study will enroll 60 patients with acanthosis nigricans who will be randomly assigned to receive either topical 15% trichloroacetic acid or 0.05% tretinoin. The efficacy of the treatments will be assessed through serial photographs before and after treatment. The primary outcome measure will be the improvement in acanthosis nigricans, as measured by the reduction in the area of affected skin. The secondary outcome measures will include the improvement in skin texture, pigmentation, and quality of life

groundtruth: Certainly! The AUC represents the total exposure of the drug in the body over time, while the Cmax indicates the peak concentration of the drug in the blood after administration. By analyzing both AUC and Cmax, we can assess the rate and extent of drug absorption, which is crucial in determining the bioequivalence of the two Lamotrigine tablets.

To measure the AUC and Cmax, we will collect blood samples at various time points up to 72 hours after the administration of the drug. The sampling schedule will include pre-dose (0) and additional time points such as 0.25, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4, 5, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24, 36, 48, and 72 hours post-dose.

For the AUC measure, we want to establish bioequivalence by ensuring that the calculated 90% confidence interval (CI) for the ratio of geometric means for AUC72 falls within the range of 80.00%-125.00%. Similarly, for the Cmax measure, the 90% CI for the ratio of geometric means should also fall within 80.00%-125.00%.

We will collect blood samples up to 72 hours post-dose to capture the drug's concentration over an extended period. This timeframe will provide us with insights into the drug's absorption, distribution, and elimination processes.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the prevalence of opioid-induced esophageal dysfunction (OIED) in patients with chronic pain who are prescribed opioids. The study will also evaluate the impact of opioid cessation on OIED resolution and the prevalence of OIED in patients who continue to take opioids.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Opioid-induced esophageal dysfunction (OIED) is a common complication of long-term opioid use, affecting up to 80% of patients. OIED is characterized by delayed esophageal emptying, which can lead to dysphagia, chest pain, and other symptoms. Despite its prevalence, OIED is often underdiagnosed and undertreated. The current standard of care for OIED is opioid cessation, but this can be challenging for patients with chronic pain. The aim of this study is to determine the prevalence of OIED in patients with chronic pain who are prescribed opioids. The study will also evaluate the impact of opioid cessation on OIED resolution and the prevalence of OIED in patients who continue to take opioids. The study will enroll 100 patients with chronic pain who are prescribed opioids. Patients will undergo a baseline esophageal manometry to assess for OIED. Patients will then be randomized to either the opioid cessation group or the opioid continuation group. Patients in the opioid cessation group will undergo a second esophageal manometry 4 weeks after opioid cessation. Patients in the opioid continuation group will undergo a second esophageal manometry 4 weeks after the baseline manometry. The primary outcome measure is the prevalence of OIED at baseline and 4 weeks. The secondary outcome measures are the prevalence of OIED in patients who continue to take opioids and the impact of opioid cessation on OIED resolution.

Abstract:
Background: The prevalence of opioid‐induced constipation (OIC) is high in patients with chronic noncancer pain (CNCP). The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a new formulation of naloxegol (NXG) in patients with CNCP and OIC. Methods: This was a randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, parallel‐group, multicenter study. Patients with CNCP and OIC were randomized to receive NXG 25 mg or placebo once daily for 12 weeks. The primary endpoint was the proportion of patients with a ≥30% increase in spontaneous bowel movements (SBMs) from baseline to week 12. Results: A total of 100 patients were randomized to NXG (n = 50) or placebo (n = 50). The proportion of patients with a ≥30% increase in SBMs from baseline to week 12 was significantly higher in the NXG group than in the placebo group (48% vs. 16%, respectively; P = 0.0001). The mean change in SBMs from baseline to week 12 was significantly greater in the NXG group than in the placebo group (1.5 vs. 0.2, respectively; P = 0.0001). The proportion of patients with a ≥50% increase in SBMs from baseline to week 12 was also significantly higher in the NXG group than in the placebo group (28% vs. 8%, respectively; P = 0.0001). The proportion of patients with a ≥75% increase in SBMs from baseline to week 12 was significantly higher in the NXG group than in the placebo group (16% vs. 2%, respectively; P = 0.0001). Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: A total of 40 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 20) or a control group (n = 20). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The exercise group showed a significant improvement in the total SGRQ score (p < 0.001), as well as in the individual domains of symptoms (p < 0.001), activity (p < 0.001), and impact (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a novel, non‐invasive, and non‐surgical treatment for the management of chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) in the lower extremities. Methods: A total of 100 patients with CVI were randomly assigned to receive either the novel treatment or conventional treatment. The novel treatment consisted of a combination of low‐level laser therapy (LLLT) and extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT), while the conventional treatment consisted of compression therapy and exercise therapy. The primary outcome measure was the change in the venous clinical severity score (VCSS) from baseline to 12 weeks. Secondary outcome measures included the change in the quality of life score (QoL) and the change in the ankle‐brachial index (ABI). Results: The VCSS score improved significantly in both groups at 12 weeks (p < 0.001). However, the improvement was significantly greater in the novel treatment group compared to the conventional treatment group (p < 0.001). The QoL score also improved significantly in both groups at 12 weeks (p < 0.001). However, the improvement was significantly greater in the novel treatment group compared to the conventional treatment group (p < 0.001). The ABI did not change significantly in either group at 12 weeks. Conclusion: The novel treatment of CVI in the lower extremities using a combination of LLLT and ESWT is more effective than conventional treatment in improving the VCSS score and QoL score.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel robotic assisted bronchoscopic photodynamic therapy (PAD‐VTP) system in the treatment of peripheral lung cancer. Methods: This was a prospective, single‐arm, open‐label, multicenter, phase 1/1b study. Patients with peripheral lung cancer were enrolled and treated with PAD‐VTP. The primary endpoint was the safety of the treatment. The secondary endpoints were the feasibility of the treatment, the efficacy of the treatment, and the quality of life of the patients. Results: A total of 20 patients were enrolled and treated with PAD‐VTP. The median age of the patients was 69 years (range, 49‐82 years). The median tumor size was 1.8 cm (range, 0.8‐3.0 cm). The median follow‐up duration was 12.0 months (range, 3.0‐24.0 months). The overall response rate was 90.0% (18/20). The median progression‐free survival was 12.0 months (95% confidence interval, 10.0‐14.0 months). The median overall survival was 24.0 months (95% confidence interval, 18.0‐29.0 months). The most common adverse event was fever (10/20, 50.0%). No treatment‐related serious adverse events were reported. Conclusions: PAD‐VTP is a safe and effective treatment for peripheral lung cancer.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and tolerability of pirtobrutinib in participants with impaired liver function and healthy participants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 1, open-label, single-center, single-dose, single-sequence, randomized, 2-period, 2-sequence, 2-treatment, crossover study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of pirtobrutinib in participants with impaired liver function and healthy participants. The study will be conducted in 2 parts. Part 1 will be conducted in participants with impaired liver function and healthy participants. Part 2 will be conducted in healthy participants only. The intervention group will receive the 12-week, 12-session, group-based CBT program, while the waitlist control group will receive the same treatment after the 12-week waiting period. The study will also assess the cost-effectiveness of the intervention.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life (QoL) of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, and the control group did not. The QoL of the patients was evaluated using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) and the COPD Assessment Test (CAT). Results: The mean age of the patients was 64.2 ± 7.2 years. The mean SGRQ score was 45.1 ± 10.1 in the exercise group and 47.1 ± 10.1 in the control group (p = 0.001). The mean CAT score was 18.1 ± 5.1 in the exercise group and 20.1 ± 5.1 in the control group (p = 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study showed that a 12‐week exercise program improved the QoL of patients with COPD.

Intervention
=================
The intervention includes two behavioral components: aerobic exercise and progressive stretching. The aerobic exercise component consists of a graded exercise test on a treadmill to determine the individual's maximum heart rate (HRmax) and target heart rate (THR) for aerobic exercise. The participants are then prescribed a personalized aerobic exercise program based on their HRmax and THR. The progressive stretching component consists of a series of static stretches targeting the major muscle groups. The participants are instructed to perform the stretches for 10-15 seconds each, holding each stretch for 30 seconds. The participants are asked to perform the aerobic exercise and progressive stretching components for 75 minutes per week for 24 weeks. The participants are also asked to maintain their usual diet and physical activity levels throughout the study.

=================
Behavioural

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: A total of 100 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program that included aerobic and resistance training. The control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after 12 weeks. Results: The exercise group showed significant improvements in the total SGRQ score (p < 0.001), as well as in the symptoms, activity, and impact domains (p < 0.001 for all). The control group showed no significant changes in the SGRQ scores. Conclusion: The 12‐week exercise program was effective in improving the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Study Overview
