Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the combination of sorafenib and lenvatinib in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a single-arm, open-label, phase II study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the combination of sorafenib and lenvatinib in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Patients will receive sorafenib 400 mg twice daily and lenvatinib 8 mg once daily until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. The primary endpoint is progression-free survival (PFS) according to modified Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (mRECIST) criteria. Secondary endpoints include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and safety.

A Single-arm, Open-label, Phase II Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of the Combination of Sorafenib and Lenvatinib in Patients With Advanced Hepatocellular Carcinoma

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and immunogenicity of the inactivated rotavirus vaccine in healthy infants and toddlers aged from 2 to 71 months.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, phase II clinical trial. The study will enroll 120 healthy infants and toddlers aged from 2 to 71 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the inactivated rotavirus vaccine or the placebo. The vaccine will be administered in two doses, with a 28-day interval between doses. The primary outcome measures are the geometric mean titers (GMTs) of anti-RV neutralizing antibodies 28 days after the final dose. The secondary outcome measures are the geometric mean increase (GMI) of neutralizing antibodies between baseline and 28 days after the final dose, and the seroconversion rates between baseline and 28 days after the final dose. The safety of the vaccine will be assessed by monitoring adverse events and serious adverse events.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized, Double-blinded, Placebo-controlled Phase II Clinical Trial of the Inactivated Rotavirus Vaccine (Vero Cells) in Toddlers and Infants Aged From 2 to 71 Months

Rotavirus Infection

-----------------
This is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, phase II clinical trial. Perfect! We now have a comprehensive set of primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial on the inactivated rotavirus vaccine. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean titer (GMT) of neutralizing antibody: Measure the GMT of neutralizing antibodies 28 days after the final dose.
2. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean increase (GMI) of neutralizing antibody: Assess the increase in neutralizing antibodies from baseline to 28 days after the final dose.
3. Immunogenicity index-seroconversion rates of neutralizing antibody: Determine the proportion of participants who develop a seropositive response between baseline and 28 days after the final dose.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Safety index-incidence of adverse reactions/events: Monitor the incidence of adverse reactions/events within 30 minutes after each dose.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the CytoSorb device in patients with acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF). The study will enroll patients with ACLF who are receiving standard medical care and will be randomized to receive either the CytoSorb device or standard medical care alone. The primary outcome measure is the change in serum bilirubin levels at 24 and 72 hours after treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in ammonia levels, the severity of hepatic encephalopathy, and mortality rates.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will enroll patients with ACLF who are receiving standard medical care and will be randomized to receive either the CytoSorb device or standard medical care alone. The CytoSorb device will be used to remove toxins from the blood, including bilirubin, ammonia, and other substances that contribute to liver failure. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of the CytoSorb device in reducing serum bilirubin levels, improving ammonia levels and the severity of hepatic encephalopathy, and reducing mortality rates. The study will also evaluate the impact of the CytoSorb device on quality of life and patient satisfaction.

Official Title

A Prospective, Randomized, Controlled, Single-Center Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of the CytoSorb Device in Patients With Acute-On-Chronic Liver Failure

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new formulation of a fixed‐dose combination of 100 mg of lisinopril and 20 mg of hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) in patients with hypertension. Methods: This was a multicenter, randomized, double‐blind, parallel‐group, active‐controlled study. Patients with hypertension were randomized to receive either the new formulation of lisinopril/HCTZ or the reference formulation of lisinopril/HCTZ. The primary efficacy endpoint was the change from baseline in systolic blood pressure (SBP) at week 12. Results: A total of 1,000 patients were randomized to receive the new formulation of lisinopril/HCTZ (n = 500) or the reference formulation of lisinopril/HCTZ (n = 500). The mean change from baseline in SBP at week 12 was ‐16.1 mmHg in the new formulation group and ‐15.9 mmHg in the reference formulation group. The mean change from baseline in diastolic blood pressure (DBP) at week 12 was ‐9.3 mmHg in the new formulation group and ‐9.2 mmHg in the reference formulation group. The mean change from baseline in pulse rate at week 12 was ‐3.8 beats per minute in the new formulation group and ‐3.7 beats per minute in the reference formulation group. The most common adverse events were dizziness, headache, and fatigue. Conclusions: The new formulation of lisinopril/HCTZ was noninferior to the reference formulation of lisinopril/HCTZ in terms of efficacy and safety.

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new drug, XEN1101, in the treatment of epilepsy. Methods: This was a multicenter, open‐label, long‐term study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, PK, and efficacy of XEN1101 in subjects diagnosed with epilepsy. The study consisted of a 12‐week open‐label treatment period and a 12‐week open‐label extension period. The primary outcome measure was the adverse events, and the secondary outcome measures were the change in monthly seizure rate, the proportion of responders, the change in Clinical Global Impression of Severity (CGI‐S) scores, the change in Patient Global Impression of Severity (PGI‐S) scores, and the change in Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory (QOLIE‐31) scores. Results: A total of 100 subjects were enrolled in the study, and 98 subjects completed the study. The most common adverse events were dizziness, headache, and somnolence. The mean change in monthly seizure rate from baseline to the end of the treatment period was ‐2.0 seizures per month. The proportion of responders (subjects experiencing ≥50% reduction in seizure frequency from baseline) was 42.9% at the end of the treatment period. The mean change in CGI‐S scores from baseline to the end of the treatment period was ‐0.8. The mean change in PGI‐S scores from baseline to the end of the treatment period was ‐0.8. The mean change in QOLIE‐31 scores from baseline to the end of the treatment period was 10.1. Conclusion: XEN1101 was well tolerated and effective in reducing seizure frequency in subjects with epilepsy. The study results suggest that XEN1101 may be a promising treatment option for epilepsy.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a 12‐week exercise program in patients with chronic low back pain (LBP). Methods: A total of 100 patients with chronic LBP were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, which included stretching, strengthening, and aerobic exercises. The control group received no intervention. The primary outcome measure was the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI). Secondary outcome measures included the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, the Roland‐Morris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ), and the Short‐Form 36 (SF‐36) questionnaire. Results: After 12 weeks, the exercise group showed significant improvements in the ODI (p < 0.001), VAS (p < 0.001), RMDQ (p < 0.001), and SF‐36 (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program is effective in improving functional outcomes and reducing pain in patients with chronic LBP.

Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a 12‐week exercise program in patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP). Methods: A total of 100 patients with CLBP were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group received no intervention. The primary outcome measure was the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI), and the secondary outcome measures were the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, the Roland‐Morris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ), and the Short Form‐36 (SF‐36). Results: After 12 weeks, the exercise group showed significant improvements in the ODI, VAS, RMDQ, and SF‐36 compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program is effective in improving disability, pain, and quality of life in patients with CLBP.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a new method of endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) for the treatment of early gastric cancer (EGC) with a large lesion size. Methods: A total of 100 patients with EGC were randomly divided into two groups. Group A (n = 50) underwent ESD using a new method, and group B (n = 50) underwent ESD using a conventional method. The new method involved the use of a transparent cap to protect the submucosal layer during ESD. The primary outcome was the en bloc resection rate, and the secondary outcomes included the procedure time, the number of pieces, the rate of postoperative bleeding, and the rate of postoperative perforation. Results: The en bloc resection rate was 98% in group A and 96% in group B (P = 0.62). The procedure time was significantly shorter in group A than in group B (100.2 ± 22.4 min vs. 120.4 ± 25.3 min, P < 0.001). The number of pieces was significantly lower in group A than in group B (1.8 ± 0.5 vs. 2.2 ± 0.6, P < 0.001). The rate of postoperative bleeding was significantly lower in group A than in group B (0% vs. 4%, P = 0.04). The rate of postoperative perforation was significantly lower in group A than in group B (0% vs. 4%, P = 0.04). Conclusions: The new method of ESD using a transparent cap is a safe and effective method for the treatment of EGC with a large lesion size.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new device for the treatment of acute ischemic stroke. Methods: This was a prospective, single‐center, open‐label, single‐arm study. Patients with acute ischemic stroke were treated with the new device within 6 hours of symptom onset. The primary outcome measure was the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score at 90 days. Secondary outcome measures included the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score, the Barthel Index (BI), and the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score at 30 days. Results: A total of 100 patients were enrolled in the study. The mean age of the patients was 65.5 years, and 55.0% were male. The mean NIHSS score at baseline was 13.5. The mean mRS score at 90 days was 2.1, and the mean BI score at 90 days was 82.0. The mean NIHSS score at 30 days was 5.0, and the mean mRS score at 30 days was 2.0. There were no device‐related serious adverse events. Conclusion: The new device was effective and safe for the treatment of acute ischemic stroke.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a new method of endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS) in the treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) with nasal polyps (NP). Methods: A total of 100 patients with CRS with NP were randomly divided into two groups. Group A (n = 50) underwent ESS using the new method, while group B (n = 50) underwent conventional ESS. The new method involved the use of a microdebrider to remove the mucosa and polyps, followed by the use of a balloon catheter to dilate the sinus ostia. The conventional method involved the use of a microdebrider to remove the mucosa and polyps, followed by the use of a curette to dilate the sinus ostia. The outcomes were assessed using the Lund‐Mackay score (LMS), the Sino‐Nasal Outcome Test‐22 (SNOT‐22), and the visual analog scale (VAS) for nasal obstruction. Results: The mean LMS score at 12 months was significantly lower in group A compared to group B (p < 0.001). The mean SNOT‐22 score at 12 months was significantly lower in group A compared to group B (p < 0.001). The mean VAS score for nasal obstruction at 12 months was significantly lower in group A compared to group B (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The new method of ESS using a microdebrider and a balloon catheter is more effective than the conventional method in the treatment of CRS with NP.

Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of subcutaneous amlitelimab on background topical corticosteroids therapy in adults with moderate-to-severe AD who have had an inadequate response to prior biologic therapy or an oral JAK inhibitor.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to compare the efficacy and safety of hot and cold endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) for large colorectal polyps. Methods: This was a prospective, randomized, controlled trial. Patients with large colorectal polyps (≥20 mm) were randomly assigned to undergo either hot EMR or cold EMR. The primary outcome was the complete resection rate of the polyp. The secondary outcomes were the rate of intraprocedural adverse events, the rate of delayed bleeding, and the rate of recurrence. Results: A total of 100 patients were enrolled in the study, with 50 patients in each group. The complete resection rate was 98% in the hot EMR group and 96% in the cold EMR group (P=0.68). There was no significant difference in the rate of intraprocedural adverse events between the two groups (P=0.22). The rate of delayed bleeding was 2% in the hot EMR group and 4% in the cold EMR group (P=0.42). The rate of recurrence was 2% in the hot EMR group and 4% in the cold EMR group (P=0.42). Conclusion: Hot and cold EMR have similar efficacy and safety for the resection of large colorectal polyps.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to assess the accuracy of the Rapid Mood Screener (RMS) in identifying participants with Bipolar 1 Disorder and Unipolar Major Depressive Disorder in a real-world setting. The study will involve administering the RMS questionnaire to participants and comparing the results with the Mini-International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI) interview.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in a real-world setting, where participants will be recruited from various sources, including healthcare providers, community organizations, and social media platforms. The study will involve two phases: screening and validation. In the screening phase, participants will be administered the RMS questionnaire, which consists of 10 questions designed to assess mood and symptoms of depression and mania. The questionnaire will be administered electronically or in paper format, depending on the participant's preference. The RMS questionnaire will take approximately 5-10 minutes to complete. In the validation phase, participants will undergo a MINI interview, which is a structured diagnostic interview that assesses for the presence of mental disorders. The MINI interview will be conducted by a trained clinician and will take approximately 15-30 minutes to complete. The MINI interview will be used to determine the presence or absence of Bipolar 1 Disorder and Unipolar Major Depressive Disorder. The results of the RMS questionnaire and MINI interview will be compared to assess the accuracy of the RMS in identifying participants with Bipolar 1 Disorder and Unipolar Major Depressive Disorder. The study will also assess the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) of the RMS questionnaire. The study will enroll a total of 1000 participants, with an equal number of participants with Bipolar 1 Disorder and Unipolar Major Depressive Disorder. The study will be conducted in accordance with the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki and all applicable regulatory requirements.

Study to Assess Accuracy of Rapid Mood Screener in Adult Particip

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new formulation of the antihypertensive drug amlodipine in patients with hypertension. Methods: A total of 100 patients with hypertension were randomly assigned to receive either amlodipine 5 mg or amlodipine 10 mg once daily for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the change in systolic blood pressure (SBP) from baseline to week 12. Secondary outcome measures included the change in diastolic blood pressure (DBP), the proportion of patients achieving a target blood pressure (BP) of <140/90 mmHg, and the incidence of adverse events. Results: The mean change in SBP from baseline to week 12 was ‐11.2 ± 10.0 mmHg in the amlodipine 5 mg group and ‐12.0 ± 10.0 mmHg in the amlodipine 10 mg group (p = 0.22). The mean change in DBP from baseline to week 12 was ‐6.8 ± 7.0 mmHg in the amlodipine 5 mg group and ‐7.0 ± 7.0 mmHg in the amlodipine 10 mg group (p = 0.22). The proportion of patients achieving a target BP of <140/90 mmHg was 60.0% in the amlodipine 5 mg group and 65.0% in the amlodipine 10 mg group (p = 0.22). The incidence of adverse events was similar in both groups. Conclusion: The new formulation of amlodipine was effective and well‐tolerated in patients with hypertension.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a 12-week, 1000 mg/day dose of atorvastatin in reducing the risk of recurrent stroke in patients with a history of ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a 12-week, 1000 mg/day dose of atorvastatin in reducing the risk of recurrent stroke in patients with a history of ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA). The study will be conducted in a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled design. Patients will be randomized to receive either atorvastatin or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of recurrent stroke during the 12-week treatment period. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in lipid levels, blood pressure, and other cardiovascular risk factors.

-----------------
A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial of Atorvastatin in the Prevention of Recurrent Stroke in Patients With a History of Ischemic Stroke or Transient Ischemic Attack

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a new treatment for patients with chronic low back pain. The treatment is a combination of physical therapy and acupuncture. The study will compare the effectiveness of this treatment to a standard treatment for chronic low back pain.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a new treatment for patients with chronic low back pain. The treatment is a combination of physical therapy and acupuncture. The study will compare the effectiveness of this treatment to a standard treatment for chronic low back pain. The study will be conducted at the University of California, San Francisco. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups. One group will receive the new treatment, and the other group will receive the standard treatment. Both groups will receive 12 sessions of treatment over a period of 12 weeks. The new treatment will consist of physical therapy and acupuncture. The physical therapy will focus on strengthening the muscles in the back and improving flexibility. The acupuncture will be performed by a licensed acupuncturist. The standard treatment will consist of physical therapy and medication. The physical therapy will focus on strengthening the muscles in the back and improving flexibility. The medication will be a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). Both groups will be asked to complete questionnaires before and after the treatment. The questionnaires will assess pain, disability, and quality of life.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized Controlled Trial of Acupuncture and Physical Therapy for Chronic Low Back Pain

Conditions
-----------------
Low Back Pain

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Other: Acupuncture
* Other: Physical Therapy

Eligibility Criteria

Inclusion Criteria: Chronic low back pain for at least 3 months Exclusion Criteria: Pregnancy or breastfeeding History of spinal surgery or fracture History of cancer or other serious medical condition

Ages Eligible for Study
-----------------
Minimum Age: 18 Years

Sexes Eligible for Study
-----------------
All

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of a 12‐week, high‐intensity, progressive resistance training (PRT) program on body composition, strength, and physical function in older adults with knee osteoarthritis (OA). Methods: A total of 100 older adults with knee OA were randomly assigned to either a PRT group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The PRT group participated in a 12‐week, high‐intensity, progressive resistance training program, while the control group received usual care. Body composition, strength, and physical function were assessed at baseline and at 12 weeks. Results: The PRT group showed significant improvements in body composition, strength, and physical function compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week, high‐intensity, progressive resistance training program is an effective intervention for improving body composition, strength, and physical function in older adults with knee OA.

Abstract:
Background: Pre‐eclampsia is a serious complication of pregnancy that can lead to maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of beetroot juice supplementation on the incidence of pre‐eclampsia in pregnant women with chronic hypertension. Methods: This randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled trial was conducted on 100 pregnant women with chronic hypertension. Participants were randomly assigned to receive either beetroot juice supplementation or a placebo. The primary outcome measure was the incidence of pre‐eclampsia, and the secondary outcome measures were blood pressure control and maternal and fetal outcomes. Results: The incidence of pre‐eclampsia was significantly lower in the beetroot juice group compared to the placebo group (10% vs. 30%, p = 0.02). Blood pressure control was also significantly better in the beetroot juice group compared to the placebo group (p = 0.001). There were no significant differences in maternal and fetal outcomes between the two groups. Conclusion: Beetroot juice supplementation may be an effective and safe intervention for reducing the incidence of pre‐eclampsia in pregnant women with chronic hypertension.

Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the clinical performance of the REEV SENSE gait tracker in measuring gait features in individuals with post‐stroke gait impairment. Methods: A total of 10 participants with post‐stroke gait impairment were recruited for this study. The participants were asked to walk on a treadmill at a self‐selected speed for 10 minutes. The REEV SENSE device and a motion capture system were used to measure gait features, including walking speed, KPP (Knee Position Predictor) measure precision, walking cadence measure precision, stride length measure precision, swing time measure precision, stance time measure precision, stance symmetry measure precision, knee flexion angle measure precision in sagittal plan, and ankle flexion angle measure precision in sagittal plan. The results were compared between the two methods. Results: The results showed that the REEV SENSE device had a high correlation with the motion capture system for all gait features, with correlation coefficients ranging from 0.91 to 0.99. The mean absolute error (MAE) for walking speed was 0.03 m/s, and the mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) was 1.1%. The MAE for KPP measure precision was 0.01 rad, and the MAPE was 1.1%. Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: A total of 40 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 20) or a control group (n = 20). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The exercise group showed a significant improvement in the total SGRQ score (p < 0.001), as well as in the individual domains of symptoms (p < 0.001), activity (p < 0.001), and impact (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: Cemiplimab is a human monoclonal antibody that blocks the PD‐1 receptor and is approved for the treatment of advanced non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). However, there is limited real‐world data on the efficacy and safety of cemiplimab in combination with platinum‐doublet chemotherapy in the first‐line treatment of advanced NSCLC. Methods: This is a retrospective, observational study of patients with advanced NSCLC who received cemiplimab in combination with platinum‐doublet chemotherapy as first‐line treatment in the United States. The primary outcome measure is the real‐world response rate (rwRR), defined as the proportion of patients who achieve a partial response or complete response according to RECIST v1.1. Secondary outcome measures include the real‐world incidence of treatment‐emergent immune‐mediated adverse events (rwTE‐imAE), progression‐free survival (PFS), and overall survival (OS). Results: A total of 100 patients were included in the study. The median age was 67 years (range 42‐84), and 58% were male. The most common histology was adenocarcinoma (70%), and 60% of patients had a performance status of 0 or 1. The median number of cycles of cemiplimab and platinum‐doublet chemotherapy was 4 (range 1‐12). The rwRR was 40% (95% CI 27‐53), and the median PFS was 10.1 months (95% CI 7.1‐13.1). The most common rwTE‐imAEs were hypothyroidism (10%), pneumonitis (7%), and colitis (5%). Conclusions: In this real‐world study, cemiplimab in combination with

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new treatment regimen for patients with advanced non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Methods: This was a single‐arm, open‐label, phase II study. Patients with advanced NSCLC were treated with cemiplimab in combination with platinum‐doublet chemotherapy for 4 cycles, followed by cemiplimab monotherapy until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. The primary endpoint was the overall response rate (ORR) according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) version 1.1. Secondary endpoints included progression‐free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and safety. Results: A total of 30 patients were enrolled in the study. The median age was 65 years (range, 42‐78 years), and 20 patients (66.7%) were male. The most common histological subtype was adenocarcinoma (n = 22, 73.3%). The ORR was 60.0% (95% confidence interval [CI], 41.2‐76.8%), with a median duration of response of 10.0 months (95% CI, 5.0‐15.0 months). The median PFS was 10.0 months (95% CI, 5.0‐15.0 months), and the median OS was not reached. The most common grade 3/4 adverse events were neutropenia (n = 10, 33.3%), anemia (n = 5, 16.7%), and thrombocytopenia (n = 5, 16.7%). Conclusions: The new treatment regimen showed promising efficacy and manageable safety in patients with advanced NSCLC. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new formulation of a fixed‐dose combination of 100 mg of amlodipine and 10 mg of valsartan (Amlodipine/Valsartan FDC) in patients with hypertension. Methods: This was a randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, parallel‐group, multicenter study. Patients with hypertension were randomized to receive either Amlodipine/Valsartan FDC or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary endpoint was the change in systolic blood pressure (SBP) from baseline to week 12. Results: A total of 100 patients were randomized to receive Amlodipine/Valsartan FDC (n = 50) or placebo (n = 50). The mean change in SBP from baseline to week 12 was ‐13.1 mmHg in the Amlodipine/Valsartan FDC group and ‐1.9 mmHg in the placebo group (p < 0.001). The mean change in diastolic blood pressure (DBP) from baseline to week 12 was ‐8.1 mmHg in the Amlodipine/Valsartan FDC group and ‐1.9 mmHg in the placebo group (p < 0.001). The mean change in pulse rate from baseline to week 12 was ‐2.9 beats per minute in the Amlodipine/Valsartan FDC group and ‐0.1 beats per minute in the placebo group (p < 0.001). 1. Introduction
Heart failure (HF) is a chronic and progressive condition that affects millions of people worldwide. It is characterized by the inability of the heart to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs, leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in the legs and feet. Acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) is a common complication of HF, which occurs when the symptoms of HF worsen suddenly and require urgent medical attention. ADHF is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates, and it is a major cause of hospitalization and readmission in patients with HF.
The pathophysiology of ADHF is complex and involves a variety of factors, including inflammation, oxidative stress, and neurohormonal activation. Inflammation plays a crucial role in the development and progression of HF, and it is associated with worse outcomes in patients with HF. Inflammatory cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and C-reactive protein (CRP), are elevated in patients with HF and are associated with worse outcomes.
Copaxone is a drug that is commonly used to treat multiple sclerosis (MS). It is a synthetic form of interferon-β-1a, which is a protein that is naturally produced by the body to regulate the immune system. Copaxone has been shown to have anti-inflammatory effects in patients with MS, and it has been proposed as a potential treatment for HF.
The aim of this study is to assess the anti-inflammatory effects of short-term Copaxone therapy on patients with ADHF. The study will compare the changes in inflammatory cytokines and clinical outcomes between patients who receive Copaxone therapy and those who receive standard care.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a prospective, single-arm, single-center, single-group assignment clinical trial. The study will enroll 100 patients with lumbar disc herniation with compressive radiculopathy who require partial discectomy. The study will be conducted at a single center in the United States. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of the PerQdisc Nucleus Replacement System in the treatment of lumbar disc herniation with compressive radiculopathy. The primary outcome measure will be the number of patients with serious adverse events related to the PerQdisc Device or the PerQdisc Surgical Procedure. The secondary outcome measures will include the change in Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) comparing baseline to follow-up visits using a patient-reported outcome tool, change in back pain values as measured by the 100 millimeter Visual Analog Scale (VAS) comparing baseline to follow-up visits, change in leg pain values as measured by the 100 millimeter Visual Analog Scale (VAS) comparing baseline to follow-up visits, and change in level of pain medication used comparing baseline to follow-up visits based on a medication scale from 0 (no meds) to 4 (high dose opioids).

-----------------
This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group, multicenter study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of the SGLT2 inhibitor dapagliflozin and the sGC stimulator riociguat in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). The disease control rate (DCR) is defined as the percentage of participants whose best overall response was either complete response (CR), partial response (PR), or stable disease (SD). Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, single-arm, multicenter study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Linvoseltamab in participants with high-risk smoldering multiple myeloma.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, single-arm, multicenter study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Linvoseltamab in participants with high-risk smoldering multiple myeloma. The study will enroll approximately 100 participants with high-risk smoldering multiple myeloma who have not received prior treatment. Participants will receive Linvoseltamab intravenously every 2 weeks for up to 24 months. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the safety and tolerability of Linvoseltamab in participants with high-risk smoldering multiple myeloma. The secondary objectives of the study are to evaluate the efficacy of Linvoseltamab in participants with high-risk smoldering multiple myeloma, including the rate of complete response (CR) as determined by the investigator, the rate of minimal residual disease (MRD) negativity at 12 months and at 24 months, and the duration of response.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of non-invasive neuromodulation on illness awareness in schizophrenia.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Schizophrenia is a severe mental disorder that affects approximately 1% of the population. It is characterized by positive symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions, as well as negative symptoms such as apathy and social withdrawal. One of the most common symptoms of schizophrenia is anosognosia, which is a lack of awareness of one's illness. Anosognosia can lead to poor treatment adherence, poor self-care, and increased risk of relapse. Non-invasive neuromodulation is a promising treatment approach for schizophrenia that involves using electrical or magnetic stimulation to modulate brain activity. Previous studies have shown that non-invasive neuromodulation can improve symptoms of schizophrenia, including positive and negative symptoms. However, the effects of non-invasive neuromodulation on illness awareness in schizophrenia have not been well studied. The investigators propose to conduct a randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled trial to determine the effects of non-invasive neuromodulation on illness awareness in schizophrenia. The investigators will recruit 40 participants with schizophrenia and anosognosia who are currently receiving treatment at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) Medical Center. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either active or sham non-invasive neuromodulation for 4 weeks. The investigators will use a questionnaire to assess illness awareness before and after the intervention. The investigators will also use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure brain

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of robot-assisted training on motor function, physical function, fatigue, and quality of life in a moderately-to-severely impaired chronic stroke population following subacute rehabilitation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in a single-blinded, randomized controlled trial. The participants will be randomly assigned to either the robot-assisted training group or the standard training group. The robot-assisted training group will receive 30 minutes of robot-assisted training per day, 5 days per week for 4 weeks. The standard training group will receive 30 minutes of standard training per day, 5 days per week for 4 weeks. Both groups will receive 30 minutes of conventional rehabilitation therapy per day, 5 days per week for 4 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the Fugl-Meyer Lower Extremity Assessment (FM-LE). The secondary outcome measures are the Fugl-Meyer Upper Extremity Assessment (FM-UE), the Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS), the 10-meter walk test (10MWT), the Timed Up and Go test (TUG), the 6-minute walk test (6MWT), the Stroke Impact Scale (SIS), the Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS), and the EuroQol 5-dimension 5-level (EQ-5D-5L). The outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months post-stroke.

-----------------
Robot-Assisted Training Versus Standard Training in Ischemic Stroke: A Single-Blinded, Randomized Controlled Trial

Stroke

* Other: Robot-assisted training
* Other: Standard training

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic heart failure. Methods: A total of 100 patients with chronic heart failure were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group received usual care. The quality of life was assessed using the Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire (MLHFQ) at baseline and after 12 weeks. Results: The exercise group showed a significant improvement in the MLHFQ total score (p < 0.001) and all subscales (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. Conclusion: The exercise program was effective in improving the quality of life of patients with chronic heart failure.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of a 12-week, 3-times-per-week, 60-minute, home-based exercise program on the physical and psychological health of older adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of a 12-week, 3-times-per-week, 60-minute, home-based exercise program on the physical and psychological health of older adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the exercise group or the control group. The exercise group will participate in a 12-week, 3-times-per-week, 60-minute, home-based exercise program that includes aerobic, strength, and flexibility exercises. The control group will not participate in any exercise program. Both groups will be assessed at baseline and at the end of the 12-week intervention period. The primary outcome measure will be the 6-minute walk test, which will be used to assess the participants' physical fitness. Secondary outcome measures will include the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire, the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale, and the COPD Assessment Test.

Effects of a Home-Based Exercise Program on the Physical and Psychological Health of Older Adults With Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of a 12-week, 3-times-per-week, 60-minute, supervised, home-based exercise program on the functional status of patients with chronic stroke.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of a 12-week, 3-times-per-week, 60-minute, supervised, home-based exercise program on the functional status of patients with chronic stroke. The study will be conducted in a randomized, controlled, single-blinded, parallel-group design. The study will be conducted in a single center. The study will include 40 patients with chronic stroke. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group will receive a 12-week, 3-times-per-week, 60-minute, supervised, home-based exercise program. The control group will receive usual care. The primary outcome measure will be the Functional Independence Measure (FIM). The secondary outcome measures will be the Barthel Index, the Modified Barthel Index, the Berg Balance Scale, the Timed Up and Go Test, the 6-Minute Walk Test, the Stroke Impact Scale, and the Stroke Specific Quality of Life Scale. The data will be analyzed using the intention-to-treat principle.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effect of a 12-Week, 3-Times-Per-Week, 60-Minute, Supervised, Home-Based Exercise Program on the Functional Status of Patients With Chronic Stroke

Stroke

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the feasibility of a text message intervention to promote healthy behaviors in cancer survivors and their caregivers. The study will also assess the acceptability of the intervention and its impact on health behaviors.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Cancer survivors and their caregivers often experience significant physical and psychological distress, which can negatively impact their quality of life. Healthy behaviors, such as dietary quality, physical activity, and sleep hygiene, can help improve their health and well-being. However, many cancer survivors and caregivers struggle to engage in these behaviors due to various barriers, such as lack of time, lack of motivation, and lack of support. Text message interventions have been shown to be effective in promoting healthy behaviors in other populations, but their effectiveness in cancer survivors and caregivers is unknown. This study aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a text message intervention to promote healthy behaviors in cancer survivors and their caregivers. The intervention will consist of daily text messages that provide health promotion content related to dietary quality, physical activity, and sleep hygiene behaviors. The study will enroll 100 cancer survivor/caregiver dyads and will be conducted over a 4-week period. The primary outcome measures will be the feasibility of the intervention and the acceptability of the text messages. The secondary outcome measures will be the impact of the intervention on health behaviors, quality of life, and psychological distress. The study will also assess the impact of the intervention on the relationship between the cancer survivor and their caregiver.

Eat, Play, Sleep: A Text Message Approach to Promoting Healthy Behaviors for Cancer Survivors and Their Caregivers

groundtruth:
Great! We have now discussed the primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. Albumin degradation rate by stable isotope:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to determine the catabolic rate of albumin by measuring the disappearance rate of 2H5-phenylalanine labeled albumin over time in blood samples. It will be compared between patients with liver disease and healthy volunteers.
   - Time Frame: The albumin degradation rate will be measured over a period of 12 weeks.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Albumin synthesis rate:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure involves comparing the oral flooding dose with historical controls where the isotope was given intravenously to measure albumin synthesis rates in volunteers and patients with liver disease.
   - Time Frame: The albumin synthesis rate will be assessed within 120 minutes after the administration of the stable isotope labeled amino acid.

2. Albumin degradation by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over time:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to investigate the relationship between oxidation and degradation of albumin by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over a period of 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The modeling of albumin degradation based on oxidized fractions will be conducted over a 12-week period.

3. Correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure seeks to determine if there is a correlation between oxidation fraction and albumin degradation rate, particularly in patients with liver disease over 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin will be assessed over a 12-week period.
You're welcome! I'm glad you find the outcome measures well-designed. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask. Good luck with your clinical trial!

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the feasibility of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a novel intervention to improve the quality of life of patients with advanced cancer. The intervention is a 12-week, 12-session, group-based, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) program. The study will also examine the effects of the intervention on quality of life, mood, and pain.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a novel intervention to improve the quality of life of patients with advanced cancer. The intervention is a 12-week, 12-session, group-based, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) program. The study will also examine the effects of the intervention on quality of life, mood, and pain. The study will be conducted at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center (HDFCCC). The study will enroll 100 patients with advanced cancer who are receiving palliative care. Patients will be randomized to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive the CBT intervention, and the control group will receive usual care. The CBT intervention will be delivered by a trained psychologist or social worker. The intervention will focus on helping patients to manage their symptoms, improve their quality of life, and cope with their illness. The control group will receive usual care, which may include referrals to other services, such as support groups or counseling. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks. At the end of the study, patients in both groups will be asked to complete a questionnaire about their quality of life, mood, and pain. The study will also collect data on the number of hospitalizations, the number of emergency room visits, and the number of days spent in the hospital.

A Randomized Controlled Trial of a Novel Intervention to Improve the Quality of Life of Patients With Advanced Cancer

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with lumbar spinal stenosis. Methods: A total of 60 patients with lumbar spinal stenosis were randomly assigned to either an exercise group or a control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group received usual care. The quality of life was assessed using the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) and the Short Form‐36 (SF‐36) questionnaire at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The exercise group showed significant improvements in the ODI and SF‐36 scores compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with lumbar spinal stenosis.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of preoperative zinc supplementation on the length of hospital stay in children with Hirschsprung's disease. Methods: This randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled trial was conducted on 50 children with Hirschsprung's disease who were admitted to the pediatric surgery ward of a university hospital in Iran. The patients were randomly assigned to two groups: the intervention group received zinc supplementation (20 mg/day) for 7 days before surgery, and the control group received a placebo. The length of hospital stay was measured as the primary outcome. The secondary outcomes included the incidence of postoperative complications, the duration of postoperative ileus, and the duration of postoperative analgesia. Results: The mean length of hospital stay was significantly shorter in the intervention group compared to the control group (4.2 ± 1.1 vs. 5.1 ± 1.2 days, p = 0.001). The incidence of postoperative complications was similar in both groups (p = 0.12). The duration of postoperative ileus and the duration of postoperative analgesia were also similar in both groups (p = 0.12 and p = 0.12, respectively). Conclusion: Preoperative zinc supplementation can reduce the length of hospital stay in children with Hirschsprung's disease without increasing the risk of postoperative complications.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of preoperative zinc supplementation on the duration of hospital stay in children operated for elective surgery for Hirschsprung's disease. Methods: This randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled trial was conducted in the pediatric surgery department of a tertiary care hospital in India. Children aged 1‐12 years with Hirschsprung's disease who were scheduled for elective surgery were included in the study. The patients were randomly allocated into two groups: the zinc group and the placebo group. The zinc group received zinc supplementation for 7 days before surgery, while the placebo group received a placebo. The duration of hospital stay in hours was measured in both groups and compared. Results: A total of 50 children were included in the study, with 25 in each group. The mean age of the children in the zinc group was 4.5 years, and the mean age of the children in the placebo group was 4.2 years. The mean duration of hospital stay in the zinc group was 4.2 days, while the mean duration of hospital stay in the placebo group was 4.5 days. There was no significant difference in the duration of hospital stay between the two groups (p = 0.58). Conclusion: Preoperative zinc supplementation did not significantly reduce the duration of hospital stay in children operated for elective surgery for Hirschsprung's disease.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of preoperative zinc supplementation on the duration of hospital stay in children operated for elective surgery for Hirschsprung's disease. Methods: This randomized controlled trial was conducted at the Department of Pediatric Surgery, Ain Shams University Children's Hospital, Cairo, Egypt, from January 2021 to December 2021. The study included 50 children aged 1 month to 10 years who were diagnosed with Hirschsprung's disease and were scheduled for elective surgery. The children were randomly assigned to two groups: the intervention group (n = 25) received zinc supplementation for seven days before surgery, and the control group (n = 25) received standard care without zinc supplementation. The primary outcome measure was the duration of hospital stay in hours. The secondary outcome measures included inflammatory markers such as C‐reactive protein (CRP) and CRP/albumin ratio, and the occurrence of postoperative complications. Results: The mean duration of hospital stay was significantly shorter in the intervention group compared to the control group (3.8 ± 0.9 vs. 4.5 ± 1.1 days, p = 0.001). The mean CRP level was significantly lower in the intervention group compared to the control group (1.2 ± 0.4 vs. 1.8 ± 0.5 mg/L, p = 0.001). The mean CRP/albumin ratio was also significantly lower in the intervention group compared to the control group (0.08 ± 0.02 vs. 0.11 ± 0.03, p = 0.001). The occurrence of postoperative complications was significantly lower in the intervention group compared to the control group (12% vs. 36%, p = 0.001). Conclusion: Preoperative zinc supplementation for seven days before surgery in children with Hirschsprung's disease resulted in a shorter duration of hospital stay, lower inflammatory markers, and a lower incidence of postoperative complications compared

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not. The quality of life of the patients was evaluated using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) before and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 64.3 ± 7.2 years, and the mean body mass index was 28.2 ± 4.1 kg/m2. The mean SGRQ score was 45.3 ± 10.2 before the intervention and 38.2 ± 10.1 after the intervention in the exercise group, and 45.3 ± 10.2 before the intervention and 45.1 ± 10.1 after the intervention in the control group. The mean SGRQ score was significantly lower in the exercise group than in the control group after the intervention (p = 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of a 12-week yoga program on pain, function, and quality of life in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be a randomized, controlled, single-blinded trial. Participants will be randomized to either an active tDCS or sham tDCS group. Both groups will receive the same yoga program. The yoga program will consist of 12 weekly sessions, each lasting 60 minutes. The yoga program will be led by a certified yoga instructor and will include a combination of gentle stretching, breathing exercises, and meditation. Participants will be asked to complete questionnaires at baseline, after the 12-week intervention, and at a 3-month follow-up. The primary outcome measure will be pain, measured using a visual analog scale. Secondary outcome measures will include function, measured using the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC), and quality of life, measured using the Short Form-36 (SF-36).

The Effect of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation and Yoga on Pain, Function, and Quality of Life in Individuals With Knee Osteoarthritis

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with knee osteoarthritis. Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with knee osteoarthritis who were referred to the physiotherapy clinic of the Imam Reza Hospital in Mashhad, Iran. The patients were randomly divided into two groups of exercise and control. The exercise group received a 12‐week exercise program, and the control group received no intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) questionnaire before and after the intervention. Results: The mean age of the patients was 58.3 ± 10.1 years. The mean WOMAC score was 52.1 ± 12.1 in the exercise group and 51.2 ± 11.9 in the control group. The mean WOMAC score decreased from 52.1 ± 12.1 to 39.1 ± 10.1 in the exercise group and from 51.2 ± 11.9 to 47.1 ± 11.9 in the control group. The mean difference in the WOMAC score between the two groups was ‐3.0 ± 10.1 (P = 0.001). Conclusion: The results of this study showed that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with knee osteoarthritis.

The CCI has been widely used in various patient populations, including knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is endogenous pain modulation, which assesses the efficiency of pain modulation mechanisms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. We can use the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) testing method to evaluate this measure. By assessing the ascending measure of pressure pain threshold (PPT) at the anterior shin and the conditioning stimulus in the form of forearm ischemia, we can calculate the percent efficiency of CPM (%CPM) as PPT2/PPT1 multiplied by 100. This measure can provide insights into the neurobiological effects of the intervention. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new treatment regimen for patients with newly diagnosed mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). Methods: This was a single‐arm, open‐label, phase II study. Patients with newly diagnosed MCL were treated with bendamustine and rituximab (BR) for 6 cycles, followed by ibrutinib for 2 years. The primary endpoint was the 2‐year Progression‐Free Survival (PFS). Secondary endpoints included the Objective Remission Rate (ORR), Complete Remission Rate (CRR), Overall Survival (OS), and Adverse Events (AEs). Results: A total of 20 patients were enrolled in the study. The median age was 65 years (range, 43‐78 years), and 13 patients (65%) were male. The median follow‐up was 24 months (range, 12‐36 months). The 2‐year PFS was 80% (95% confidence interval [CI], 58.2‐91.8). The ORR was 95% (95% CI, 78.8‐99.9), and the CRR was 75% (95% CI, 52.9‐90.2). The median OS was not reached. The most common AEs were neutropenia (80%), thrombocytopenia (60%), and anemia (55%). Conclusions: The new treatment regimen showed promising efficacy and safety in patients with newly diagnosed MCL. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to either the exercise group (n = 30) or the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) at baseline and after 12 weeks. Results: The mean age of the participants was 65.2 ± 7.1 years, and the mean SGRQ score was 45.1 ± 10.1. There was a significant improvement in the SGRQ score in the exercise group compared to the control group (p < 0.001). Conclusion: The 12‐week exercise program was effective in improving the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effects of long-term mechanical ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. The disease is characterized by progressive muscle weakness and paralysis, which eventually leads to death. There is no cure for ALS, and the disease is progressive and fatal. Long-term mechanical ventilation support (LTMV) is a treatment option for ALS patients who have lost the ability to breathe on their own. LTMV involves the use of a ventilator to provide oxygen and air to the lungs, and it can help patients breathe more easily and improve their quality of life. However, there is limited evidence on the effects of LTMV on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families. This study aims to evaluate the effects of LTMV on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families. The study will include 100 ALS patients who have been diagnosed with the disease and are eligible for LTMV. The patients will be randomly assigned to two groups: one group will receive LTMV support, and the other group will not receive LTMV support. The patients in both groups will be followed for 21 months. The primary outcome measure is the overall quality of life assessed by the Quality of Life Scale. The measure description states that it's a total score ranging from 16 to 112, with a higher score indicating better quality of life. It will be assessed at different time points: at inclusion, 3 months, 9 months, 15 months, and 21 months after inclusion. The secondary outcome measures include the following: - The ALS Functional Rating Scale-Revised (ALSFRS-R) - The Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS) - The Medical Research Council (MRC) scale - The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) - The EuroQol-5 Dimensions-5 Levels (EQ-5D-5L

That's a great addition to the study. The EQ-5D-5L is a widely used measure of health-related quality of life, and it will provide valuable information on the impact of long-term mechanical ventilation support on patients' health-related quality of life.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effects of long-term mechanical ventilation support on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects the motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. It is characterized by muscle weakness and atrophy, which can lead to respiratory failure and death. Long-term mechanical ventilation support (LTMV) is a treatment option for ALS patients with severe respiratory insufficiency. However, the impact of LTMV on the quality of life of patients and their families is not well understood. This study aims to evaluate the effects of LTMV on the quality of life of ALS patients and their families. The study will be conducted in two arms: one with patients choosing life prolonging treatment with LTMV and their families, and the other with patients declining life prolonging treatment with LTMV and their families. The primary outcome measure is the overall quality of life assessed by the Quality of Life Scale. The measure description states that it's a total score ranging from 16 to 112, with a higher score indicating better quality of life. It will be assessed at different time points: at inclusion, 3 months, 9 months, 15 months, and 21 months after inclusion. The secondary outcome measures include the health-related quality of life assessed by the EQ-5D-5L, the disease-specific quality of life assessed by the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Assessment Scale - 5 items (ALSAQ-5), and the health-related quality of life related to severe respiratory insufficiency using the Severe Respiratory Insufficiency Questionnaire. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effects of a 12-week, home-based, multidisciplinary intervention on the quality of life of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and their caregivers. The intervention will include a combination of physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, and psychological support. The study will be conducted in two phases: a baseline phase and an intervention phase. During the baseline phase, participants will undergo a comprehensive assessment of their physical, cognitive, and emotional functioning. During the intervention phase, participants will receive the multidisciplinary intervention for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the quality of life of patients with ALS, as measured by the ALS Assessment Questionnaire (ALSAQ-40). Secondary outcome measures will include the quality of life of caregivers, as measured by the Zarit Burden Interview (ZBI), and the physical, cognitive, and emotional functioning of patients with ALS, as measured by the Functional Independence Measure (FIM), the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), and the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS). The study will also evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention, as well as the cost-effectiveness of the intervention.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. It is characterized by muscle weakness, muscle atrophy, and paralysis. The disease is fatal, with a median survival of 3-5 years after diagnosis. Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of the use of gel pillows on the sleep quality and general comfort levels of patients in the preoperative period.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of the use of gel pillows on the sleep quality and general comfort levels of patients in the preoperative period. The study will be conducted in the preoperative period of patients who will undergo elective surgery in the operating room of the hospital. The study will be conducted in two groups. The first group will be the control group, and the second group will be the intervention group. The control group will be given a standard pillow, while the intervention group will be given a gel pillow. The sleep quality of the patients will be evaluated using the Richards Campbell Sleep Scale. Each item in the scale is evaluated on a chart from 0 to 100, and the total score is calculated based on 5 items, excluding noise levels. A score of 0-25 indicates very bad sleep, while 76-100 indicates very good sleep. The time frame for this measure is 12 months.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a new device for the treatment of chronic low back pain. The device is a wearable device that uses electrical stimulation to stimulate the muscles in the lower back. The study will compare the effectiveness of the device to a placebo device.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: the treatment group or the placebo group. The treatment group will receive the active device, while the placebo group will receive a sham device. Both groups will receive the device for 12 weeks. The device will be worn for 30 minutes per day, 5 days per week. Participants will be asked to complete questionnaires at the beginning of the study, after 6 weeks of treatment, and after 12 weeks of treatment. The questionnaires will assess pain, disability, and quality of life.

Background
-----------------
Background: The treatment of acute ischemic stroke (AIS) is time-critical. The time from symptom onset to treatment is a key factor in determining the outcome of patients with AIS. In our hospital, the treatment of AIS is performed by a multidisciplinary team (MDT) consisting of neurologists, neurosurgeons, and radiologists. However, the current system for alerting the MDT for AIS patients is not standardized, and the treatment time for AIS patients may be delayed due to communication problems between the emergency department (ED) and the MDT. Therefore, we aim to implement a standardized alarming system for AIS patients to improve the treatment time and workflow of the MDT. Methods: This is a prospective observational study. We will enroll patients with AIS who are transferred to our hospital for thrombectomy. The treatment time and workflow of the MDT will be compared before and after the implementation of the standardized alarming system. The primary outcome is the treatment time, and the secondary outcome is the workflow of the MDT. The treatment time will be measured from the time the patient arrives at the ED to the time the patient is transferred to the angiography suite for thrombectomy. The workflow of the MDT will be measured by the time it takes for the MDT to be notified of the patient's arrival and the time it takes for the MDT to make a decision

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of a standardized alarming system on treatment times and workflow in stroke patients with interhospital transfer for thrombectomy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of a standardized alarming system on treatment times and workflow in stroke patients with interhospital transfer for thrombectomy. The study will be conducted as a prospective, observational study in the form of a patient registry. The study will be conducted at the University Hospital of Basel, Switzerland. The study will include all patients with acute ischemic stroke who are transferred to the University Hospital of Basel for thrombectomy. The study will start on 1st of January 2023 and will end on 31st of December 2023. The study will include a total of 100 patients. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and all applicable regulatory requirements. The study will be approved by the local ethics committee.

Intervention
=================
The study will be conducted in the emergency department of the University Hospital of Basel. All patients with acute ischemic stroke who are eligible for mechanical thrombectomy (MT) will be included in the study. The study will be conducted in two phases: a prospective phase and a retrospective phase.

In the prospective phase, the study will be conducted in two groups: a control group and an intervention group. The control group will receive standard care, while the intervention group will receive the standard care plus the implementation of a standardized MT alarming system. The intervention group will be randomized to receive the intervention in a 1:1 ratio.

In the retrospective phase, the study will be conducted in a historical control group. The historical control group will consist of patients who received standard care in the past.

Intervention
=================
The intervention group will receive the standard care plus the implementation of a standardized MT alarming system. The intervention will be implemented in the following steps:

1. Identification of the need for MT: The need for MT will be identified by the emergency physician based on the clinical presentation of the patient and the results of the initial imaging studies.

2. Activation of the MT team: The MT team will be activated by the emergency physician using a standardized alarming system. The alarming system will include a dedicated phone number, a dedicated email address, and a dedicated pager.

3. Transfer of the patient to the primary thrombectomy center: The patient will be transferred to the primary thrombectomy center as soon as possible. The transfer will be coordinated by the emergency physician and the MT team.

4. Peri-procedural care: The patient will receive standardized peri-procedural care,

8. Groin-to-recanalization time: Time from groin puncture to successful recanalization. Time frame: 24 hours.

9. Adverse events within 7 days: Adverse events within the first 7 days after transfer to the referral center. Time frame: 7 days.

Absolutely! In addition to the CR/CRh rate, there are several other important secondary outcome measures to consider. These include:

1. Incidence and severity of adverse events (safety and tolerability): We can monitor the number and grade of adverse events assessed by CTCAE v5.0 over the course of approximately 36 months. This will help us assess the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy.

2. Duration of response: Measuring the time from randomization to disease progression or death in patients who achieve CR/CRh will provide insights into the durability of treatment response.

3. Post baseline transfusion independence rate: Assessing the rate of conversion from baseline transfusion dependence to transfusion independence will help us understand the impact of treatment on patients' quality of life.

4. Progression-free survival: Evaluating the time from randomization until the first evidence of disease progression or death will provide valuable information on the treatment's ability to control disease progression and prolong survival.

5. Relapse-free survival: Monitoring the number of participants alive without relapse will help us assess the long-term effectiveness of the combination therapy in preventing disease relapse.

6. Overall survival: Measuring the time from randomization to death will provide essential data on the treatment's impact on overall survival outcomes.

7. Percentage of patients bridged to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Assessing the number of hematopoietic stem cell transplantations following response will provide insights into the potential of the combination therapy to facilitate curative treatment options.

8. Impact of treatment on HM-PRO (hematologic malignancy-specific patient-reported outcome measure): Evaluating the treatment's impact on patients' health-related quality of life and disease-related signs and symptoms using the HM-PRO scales will provide a holistic understanding of the treatment's effects.

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of this study was to determine the feasibility of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a 3‐month expressive writing intervention for transgender and nonbinary (TNB) individuals. Methods: A total of 100 TNB individuals were recruited from the community and randomized to either an expressive writing intervention or a control group. The intervention group was asked to write for 20 minutes each day for 3 months about their experiences as a TNB individual. The control group was asked to write for 20 minutes each day for 3 months about a neutral topic. Both groups completed questionnaires at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months. Results: The intervention group reported a significant decrease in internalized anti‐TNB stigma and an increase in well‐being compared to the control group. The intervention group also reported a significant increase in the number of attended writing sessions compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that an expressive writing intervention is feasible for TNB individuals and may be an effective intervention for reducing internalized anti‐TNB stigma and promoting well‐being.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of D-allulose in the treatment of constipation in children.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Constipation is a common problem in children, affecting up to 30% of the pediatric population. It is characterized by infrequent bowel movements, hard stools, and difficulty passing stools. Current treatments for constipation include dietary modifications, laxatives, and enemas. However, these treatments are often ineffective or have undesirable side effects. D-allulose is a novel sugar alcohol that has been shown to have laxative properties in adults. It is a non-caloric sweetener that is metabolized in the colon, where it draws water into the stool, making it softer and easier to pass. In this study, the investigators will evaluate the safety and efficacy of D-allulose in the treatment of constipation in children. The study will enroll 30 children aged 4-12 years with constipation. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either D-allulose or a placebo for 4 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the change in the number of bowel movements per week. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in stool consistency, abdominal pain, and quality of life. The investigators hypothesize that D-allulose will be safe and effective in the treatment of constipation in children.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a 12-week, 1000 mg/day dose of the investigational drug, AZD1480, in patients with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis (AD).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of AZD1480 in patients with moderate to severe AD. The qualitative data will be collected using focus groups and will be used to gain a deeper understanding of the participants' experiences with the intervention. The results of this study will be used to inform the development of a larger, randomized controlled trial of the Horizons Group Intervention for patients with chronic GVHD.

Brief summary
=================
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the feasibility of a group intervention for adults with chronic graft versus host disease (GVHD) who are receiving care at the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center Bone Marrow Transplant Program. The intervention is called the Horizons Group Intervention and is designed to improve coping skills, quality of life, and stem cell transplant complications. The intervention includes 8 weekly group sessions delivered via video conference by a bone marrow transplant clinician and behavioral health specialist. The sessions last approximately 1.5 hours each week and can be accessed through Zoom. Participants will also have access to an intervention manual and audio-recorded relaxation exercises. The study will enroll up to 15 participants and will be conducted over a period of 8 weeks. The primary outcome measures are the percentage of participant enrollment, the percentage of participant attendance, and the percentage of participant retention. The secondary outcome measures are the change in coping skills, quality of life, and stem cell transplant complications.
