Brief summary
=================
Chronic graft versus host disease (cGVHD) is a common complication of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT), affecting up to 70% of patients. cGVHD can cause significant physical, emotional, and social distress, leading to decreased quality of life and increased healthcare utilization. The Horizons Group intervention is a multidisciplinary intervention that aims to improve the quality of life and coping skills of patients with cGVHD. The intervention includes 8 weekly group sessions delivered via video conference by a bone marrow transplant clinician and behavioral health specialist. The sessions focus on education, coping skills, and social support. The intervention is based on the principles of cognitive behavioral therapy and mindfulness-based stress reduction. The primary objective of this study is to assess the feasibility, engagement, and long-term retention of participants in the Horizons Group intervention. The secondary objectives are to assess the impact of the intervention on quality of life, coping skills, and symptoms related to cGVHD.

Prospective, observational, multicenter study

Description
=================
The study is a prospective, observational, multicenter study. The study will be conducted in 10 centers in Spain. The study will include 100 patients aged 65 years or older who are candidates for kidney transplantation. The study will be conducted in two phases: a pre-transplant phase and a post-transplant phase. The pre-transplant phase will last for 6 months, and the post-transplant phase will last for 24 months. During the pre-transplant phase, the study participants will undergo a comprehensive geriatric assessment, which will include a physical examination, laboratory tests, and a geriatric assessment. The geriatric assessment will include assessments of mobility, cognition, self-sufficiency, and disability. The study participants will also undergo a depression screening using the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS) scale. During the post-transplant phase, the study participants will be followed up for 24 months. The study participants will be evaluated at 3, 6, 12, and 24 months after transplantation. The study participants will undergo a comprehensive geriatric assessment at each follow-up visit. The study participants will also undergo a depression screening using the GDS scale at each follow-up visit. The study participants will be evaluated for graft and patient survival, graft function, and post-transplant adverse events. The study participants will also be evaluated for functional status using the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) and the Barthel Index.

The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of a new drug, called AZD1480, in patients with scleroderma. The study will also look at how the drug affects the immune system and how it is processed by the body.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: This study was a randomized controlled trial. The study population consisted of 60 patients with COPD who were randomly assigned to the exercise group (n = 30) and the control group (n = 30). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life of the patients was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) before and after the intervention. Results: There was a significant improvement in the quality of life of the patients in the exercise group compared to the control group (p < 0.05). Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program can improve the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and efficacy of a new drug, called AZD1775, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 1, open-label, dose-escalation study of AZD1775 in patients with advanced solid tumors. The study will be conducted in two parts: Part 1 will determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase 2 dose (RP2D) of AZD1775 in patients with advanced solid tumors. Part 2 will evaluate the safety and efficacy of AZD1775 at the RP2D in patients with advanced solid tumors.

A Phase 1, Open-Label, Dose-Escalation Study of AZD1775 in Patients With Advanced Solid Tumors

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to compare the effectiveness of laparoscopic peritoneal lavage and sigmoid resection in the treatment of acute colonic diverticular disease.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Acute colonic diverticular disease is a common condition that can lead to severe complications, including perforation, abscess, and fistula formation. Laparoscopic peritoneal lavage and sigmoid resection are two surgical methods used to treat acute colonic diverticular disease. Laparoscopic peritoneal lavage involves washing the abdominal cavity with a saline solution to remove bacteria and debris, while sigmoid resection involves removing the affected portion of the colon. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of these two surgical methods in terms of clinical outcomes, including mortality, morbidity, and length of hospital stay. The study will also assess the impact of these surgical methods on patient quality of life and overall satisfaction with treatment. The study will enroll patients with acute colonic diverticular disease who are eligible for either laparoscopic peritoneal lavage or sigmoid resection. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of the two treatment groups. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of clinical success, defined as the absence of recurrent symptoms or complications at 30 days post-surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include mortality, morbidity, length of hospital stay, quality of life, and overall satisfaction with treatment. The study will also assess the cost-effectiveness of each surgical method. The study will provide valuable information on the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of laparoscopic peritoneal lavage and sigmoid resection in the treatment of acute colonic diverticular disease.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized Controlled Trial Comparing Laparoscopic Peritoneal Lav

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life (QoL) of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: A total of 100 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group received usual care. The St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) was used to assess QoL at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The exercise group showed significant improvements in the total SGRQ score (p < 0.001), as well as in the symptoms, activity, and impact domains (p < 0.001 for all). The control group showed no significant changes in any of the SGRQ domains. Conclusion: A 12‐week exercise program can improve the QoL of patients with COPD, particularly in the symptoms, activity, and impact domains.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week exercise program on the quality of life of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: A total of 100 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either an exercise group or a control group. The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The quality of life was assessed using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) and the COPD Assessment Test (CAT) at baseline and after the intervention. Results: The exercise group showed significant improvements in the SGRQ total score (p < 0.001) and the CAT score (p < 0.001) compared to the control group. Conclusion: The 12‐week exercise program was effective in improving the quality of life of patients with COPD.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 12‐week, high‐intensity, home‐based exercise program on the physical function of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Methods: A total of 100 patients with COPD were randomly assigned to either the exercise group (n = 50) or the control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week, high‐intensity, home‐based exercise program, while the control group received usual care. The primary outcome was the 6‐minute walk test (6MWT). Secondary outcomes included the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ), the Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) dyspnea scale, and the COPD Assessment Test (CAT). Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of different gastric residual volume (GRV) thresholds for holding enteral feeding on the frequency of diet volume ratio, incidence of gastrointestinal complications, days of ventilator use, and length of stay in the intensive care unit (ICU) in critically ill patients in the internal medicine intensive care unit (IM-ICU).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be conducted in the IM-ICU of a tertiary hospital in China. The study will enroll 120 critically ill patients who require enteral feeding and have a nasogastric tube in place. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: the control group (GRV threshold of 200 mL) and the experimental group (GRV threshold of 300 mL). The frequency of diet volume ratio, incidence of gastrointestinal complications, days of ventilator use, and length of stay in the ICU will be compared between the two groups.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effects of Different Gastric Residual Volume Thresholds for Holding Enteral Feeding on the Frequency of Diet Volume Ratio, Incidence of Gastrointestinal Complications, Days of Ventilator Use, and Length of Stay in the Intensive Care Unit in Critically Ill Patients in the Internal Medicine Intensive Care Unit

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Odronextamab in combination with chemotherapy in participants with previously untreated follicular lymphoma (FL).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 3, randomized, open-label, multicenter study of Odronextamab in combination with chemotherapy in participants with previously untreated FL. The study will consist of 2 parts: Part 1: Dose Escalation and Expansion Part 2: Randomized Comparison of Odronextamab in Combination with Chemotherapy to Rituximab in Combination with Chemotherapy The study will enroll approximately 150 participants in Part 1 and approximately 300 participants in Part 2. Abstract:
Background: Diabetic macular edema (DME) is a common complication of diabetes that can lead to vision loss. Intravitreal injections of anti‐vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) agents are the standard of care for DME, but some patients do not respond well to treatment. Inflammation is thought to play a role in the pathogenesis of DME, and systemic inflammatory biomarkers have been shown to be associated with treatment response in other retinal diseases. However, the relationship between systemic inflammatory biomarkers and treatment response in DME is not well understood. Methods: This is a prospective, observational study of patients with DME who are receiving intravitreal injections of anti‐VEGF agents. We will measure serum levels of inflammatory biomarkers, including ICAM‐1, MCP‐1, Il‐6, IL‐8, VEGF‐A, and TNFa, at baseline and at 3 and 6 months after the first injection. We will also measure OCT parameters, including central macular thickness (CMT), central subfield thickness (CSFT), and retinal thickness at the fovea. We will compare the levels of these biomarkers with the treatment response and OCT parameters. Results: We have enrolled 50 patients in the study so far. The mean age of the patients is 65 years, and the mean duration of diabetes is 15 years. The mean baseline CMT is 400 μm, and the mean baseline CSFT is 350 μm. The mean baseline levels of ICAM‐1, MCP‐1, Il‐6, IL‐8, VEGF‐A, and TNFa are 100 ng/mL, 200 ng/mL, 50 pg/mL, 100 pg/mL, 100 pg/mL, and 50 pg/mL, respectively. Conclusions: Our study suggests that systemic inflammatory biomarkers may be associated with treatment response and OCT parameters in patients with DME. Further studies

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a 12-week, 12-session, group-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) intervention for the treatment of insomnia in patients with chronic pain.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a 12-week, 12-session, group-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) intervention for the treatment of insomnia in patients with chronic pain. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design, with participants randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. The intervention group will receive the CBT intervention, which will be delivered in a group format and will include education about sleep, relaxation techniques, cognitive restructuring, and sleep hygiene. The control group will receive usual care, which may include medication or other treatments for insomnia. The primary outcome measure will be the change in sleep quality, as measured by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). Secondary outcome measures will include the change in pain intensity, as measured by the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI), and the change in depression and anxiety, as measured by the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS). The study will also assess the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention, as well as the cost-effectiveness of the intervention.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 1b, open-label, multicenter study of AZD1775 in combination with temozolomide in patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma. The study will be conducted in two parts. Part 1 will be a dose escalation study to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of AZD1775 in combination with temozolomide. Part 2 will be a dose expansion study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination of AZD1775 and temozolomide at the MTD determined in Part 1.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new formulation of dexamethasone (DEX) in the prevention of chemotherapy‐induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) in patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy (HEC). Methods: This was a randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, phase III study. Patients were randomized to receive either DEX 8 mg or placebo orally 30 minutes before chemotherapy and 12 hours later. The primary endpoint was complete response (CR) rate (no emesis and no rescue medication) during the acute phase (0‐24 hours). Results: A total of 100 patients were enrolled and randomized. The CR rate was 80.0% in the DEX group and 60.0% in the placebo group (P = .03). The CR rate was significantly higher in the DEX group than in the placebo group during the delayed phase (24‐120 hours) (P = .001). The incidence of nausea was significantly lower in the DEX group than in the placebo group during the acute phase (P = .001) and the delayed phase (P = .001). The incidence of vomiting was significantly lower in the DEX group than in the placebo group during the acute phase (P = .001) and the delayed phase (P = .001). The incidence of adverse events was similar between the two groups. Conclusions: The new formulation of DEX was effective and well tolerated in the prevention of CINV in patients receiving HEC.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a new method of anesthesia induction in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Methods: A total of 100 patients were randomly divided into two groups. Group A (n = 50) received 0.05 mg/kg midazolam and 2 mg/kg propofol intravenously, and Group B (n = 50) received 0.05 mg/kg midazolam and 2 mg/kg propofol intravenously followed by 0.5 mg/kg propofol intravenously. The time to loss of consciousness, time to intubation, time to extubation, and recovery time were recorded. Results: The time to loss of consciousness, time to intubation, and time to extubation were significantly shorter in Group B than in Group A (P < 0.05). The recovery time was significantly shorter in Group B than in Group A (P < 0.05). Conclusion: The new method of anesthesia induction is safe and effective in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Abstract:
Background: The prevalence of severe asthma is increasing worldwide, and it is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. The aim of this study was to evaluate the prevalence of severe asthma in a tertiary care hospital in India. Methods: This was a cross‐sectional study conducted in the Department of Pulmonary Medicine, AIIMS, New Delhi, India, from January 2019 to December 2019. Patients with a diagnosis of asthma were included in the study. The diagnosis of asthma was based on the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines. The severity of asthma was classified according to the GINA guidelines. The prevalence of severe asthma was calculated using the GINA guidelines. Results: A total of 100 patients with asthma were included in the study. The mean age of the patients was 38.6 ± 13.1 years, and the majority of the patients were males (60%). The most common symptoms of asthma were cough (80%), wheezing (70%), and shortness of breath (60%). The most common triggers of asthma were dust (40%), pollen (30%), and cold air (20%). The most common comorbidities were obesity (30%), hypertension (20%), and diabetes mellitus (10%). It helps assess the safety and potential risks associated with different anesthesia methods.

4. Medication taken for pain between these same groups of patients in the 21 days following surgery: This measure tracks the patient's daily consumption of painkillers, recorded in a patient diary for 21 days after the intervention. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of trabectedin in combination with paclitaxel and carboplatin in patients with advanced ovarian cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a phase II, open-label, single-arm, multicenter study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of trabectedin in combination with paclitaxel and carboplatin in patients with advanced ovarian cancer. The study will enroll 30 patients with advanced ovarian cancer who have not received prior chemotherapy. Patients will receive trabectedin 1.5 mg/m2 intravenously on days 1, 8, and 15 of each 28-day cycle, paclitaxel 175 mg/m2 intravenously on day 1 of each 28-day cycle, and carboplatin AUC 5 on day 1 of each 28-day cycle. Treatment will continue until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or withdrawal of consent. The primary endpoint is progression-free survival (PFS). Secondary endpoints include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and safety.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of rituximab in patients with idiopathic membranous nephropathy with nephrotic syndrome.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Idiopathic membranous nephropathy (IMN) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. The current standard of care for IMN is corticosteroids, but the response rate is only 30-40%. Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody that targets CD20, a surface antigen expressed on B cells. It has been shown to be effective in treating various autoimmune diseases, including lupus nephritis and vasculitis. However, its efficacy in treating IMN is not well established. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of rituximab in patients with IMN with nephrotic syndrome. The study will enroll 60 patients with IMN with nephrotic syndrome who have failed to respond to corticosteroids. Patients will be randomized to receive either rituximab or placebo. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of patients achieving a complete or partial remission at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include the percentage of patients achieving a complete or partial remission at 12 months, the change in proteinuria at 6 and 12 months, and the change in estimated glomerular filtration rate at 6 and 12 months. The safety of rituximab will also be evaluated by monitoring adverse events and laboratory parameters.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial of Rituximab in Patients With Idiopathic Membranous Nephropathy With Nephrotic Syndrome

Conditions
-----------------
Idiopathic Membranous Nephropathy

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to investigate the effects of perioperative neurocognitive dysfunction on the long-term cognitive function of elderly patients undergoing non-neurosurgical surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Perioperative neurocognitive dysfunction (PND) is a common complication in elderly patients undergoing non-neurosurgical surgery. It is characterized by a decline in cognitive function that occurs during or after surgery and can persist for weeks or months. PND can have a significant impact on patients' quality of life, functional independence, and overall health outcomes. Despite its prevalence and potential consequences, the long-term effects of PND on cognitive function are not well understood. This study aims to investigate the long-term effects of PND on cognitive function in elderly patients undergoing non-neurosurgical surgery. The study will enroll 100 elderly patients aged 65 years or older who are scheduled for non-neurosurgical surgery. Patients will be assessed for cognitive function preoperatively, postoperatively, and at 1-year follow-up. The primary outcome measure will be the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), which is a standardized cognitive function test that assesses various cognitive domains, including memory, attention, language, and visuospatial skills. Secondary outcome measures will include the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), the Trail Making Test (TMT), and the Digit Symbol Substitution Test (DSST). The study will also assess the association between PND and other factors, such as age, gender, education level, preoperative cognitive function, and postoperative complications. The study will provide valuable insights into the long-term effects of PND on cognitive function in elderly patients undergoing non-neurosurgical surgery. The findings of this study will help to improve the management of PND and its long-term consequences.

Official Title
-----------------

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a new treatment for patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP) and to compare it with the efficacy of a standard treatment. Methods: A total of 100 patients with CLBP were randomly assigned to two groups. The first group received a new treatment, and the second group received a standard treatment. The new treatment consisted of a combination of physical therapy and acupuncture, while the standard treatment consisted of physical therapy alone. The primary outcome measure was the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI). The secondary outcome measures were the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, the Roland‐Morris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ), and the Short Form‐36 (SF‐36). Results: The mean age of the patients was 45.2 ± 10.1 years. The mean ODI score was 40.2 ± 10.1 in the new treatment group and 41.2 ± 10.1 in the standard treatment group. The mean VAS score was 6.2 ± 1.1 in the new treatment group and 6.3 ± 1.1 in the standard treatment group. The mean RMDQ score was 10.2 ± 2.1 in the new treatment group and 10.3 ± 2.1 in the standard treatment group. The mean SF‐36 score was 60.2 ± 10.1 in the new treatment group and 60.3 ± 10.1 in the standard treatment group. There were no significant differences between the two groups in any of the outcome measures. Conclusion: The new treatment was not found to be more effective than the standard treatment in the treatment of CLBP.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a 12‐week exercise program in patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP). Methods: A total of 100 patients with CLBP were randomly assigned to either an exercise group (n = 50) or a control group (n = 50). The exercise group participated in a 12‐week exercise program, while the control group received no intervention. The primary outcome measure was the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI), and the secondary outcome measures were the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, the Roland‐Morris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ), and the Short Form‐36 (SF‐36). Results: The exercise group showed significant improvements in the ODI, VAS, RMDQ, and SF‐36 scores compared to the control group. Conclusion: The results of this study suggest that a 12‐week exercise program is effective in improving disability, pain, and quality of life in patients with CLBP.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of a new prognostic epigenetic signature in predicting early relapse in patients with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC). Methods: We conducted a retrospective analysis of 100 patients with OPSCC who underwent surgery and adjuvant therapy between 2010 and 2015. The patients were divided into two groups based on the presence or absence of a prognostic epigenetic signature. The primary outcome measure was early relapse, defined as recurrence within 18 months after treatment. The secondary outcome measure was overall survival. Results: The median follow‐up time was 36 months. The 5‐year overall survival rate was 70% in the negative prognostic epigenetic signature group and 40% in the positive prognostic epigenetic signature group (p = 0.001). The 5‐year disease‐free survival rate was 60% in the negative prognostic epigenetic signature group and 30% in the positive prognostic epigenetic signature group (p = 0.001). The negative prognostic epigenetic signature group had a significantly lower risk of early relapse compared to the positive prognostic epigenetic signature group (hazard ratio [HR] = 0.33, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 0.15‐0.72, p = 0.004). Conclusions: The new prognostic epigenetic signature can effectively predict early relapse in patients with OPSCC. This signature may be a useful tool for personalized treatment and follow‐up in patients with OPSCC.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of a single application of 1% lidocaine cream on the pain of the first injection of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) in children. Methods: This randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled study was conducted in the pediatric outpatient clinic of a tertiary care hospital. A total of 100 children aged 1‐12 years who were scheduled to receive IVIG were included in the study. The children were randomly assigned to two groups: the lidocaine group (n = 50) and the placebo group (n = 50). The children in the lidocaine group received 1% lidocaine cream, and the children in the placebo group received placebo cream. The pain was assessed using the Wong‐Baker FACES Pain Rating Scale (WBFPRS) before and after the application of the cream. Results: The mean age of the children in the lidocaine group was 6.8 ± 2.9 years, and the mean age of the children in the placebo group was 6.9 ± 2.8 years. There was no significant difference between the groups in terms of age, gender, and weight. The mean pain score before the application of the cream was 4.8 ± 1.2 in the lidocaine group and 4.9 ± 1.2 in the placebo group. The mean pain score after the application of the cream was 2.1 ± 1.1 in the lidocaine group and 3.9 ± 1.2 in the placebo group. The mean difference in pain scores between the groups was 1.8 ± 1.1 (p < 0.001). Conclusion: A single application of 1% lidocaine cream significantly reduced the pain of the first injection of IVIG in children.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a new drug, AZD1480, in patients with advanced solid tumors.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 1, open-label, dose-escalation study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and preliminary efficacy of AZD1480 in patients with advanced solid tumors. The study will be conducted in two parts: Part 1 will be a dose-escalation study to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase 2 dose (RP2D) of AZD1480. Part 2 will be a dose expansion study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and preliminary efficacy of AZD1480 at the RP2D.

Intervention
=================
The intervention is transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS). The study will be a randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either active or sham tDCS treatment. The active tDCS group will receive real tDCS treatment, while the sham tDCS group will receive a sham treatment that mimics the real treatment but does not deliver any current. The tDCS treatment will be administered for 20 minutes per session, five days a week for four weeks. The treatment will be delivered using a constant current of 2 mA, with the anode placed over the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and the cathode placed over the right supraorbital region. The treatment will be administered using a battery-powered stimulator (NeuroConn DC-Stimulator Plus).

Intervention type
=================
Device

Primary outcome measure
=================
The primary outcome measure is the change in depressive symptoms, as measured by the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HAMD). The HAMD is a validated scale that assesses the severity of depressive symptoms. The scale consists of 17 items, each scored on a scale of 0 to 4, with a total score ranging from 0 to 52. A higher score indicates more severe depressive symptoms. The change in HAMD score from baseline to the end of the treatment period will be compared between the active and sham tDCS groups.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy of a new treatment for patients with chronic low back pain. The treatment involves a combination of physical therapy and acupuncture. The study will last for 12 weeks, and participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: the treatment group or the control group. The treatment group will receive the new treatment, while the control group will receive standard care. Both groups will be asked to complete questionnaires at the beginning and end of the study to assess their pain levels and quality of life.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Low back pain is a common problem that affects millions of people worldwide. It is often caused by a variety of factors, including poor posture, muscle strain, and degenerative disc disease. While there are many treatments available for low back pain, most of them are not very effective. This study will test a new treatment that combines physical therapy and acupuncture. The treatment will be administered by a licensed physical therapist and a certified acupuncturist. The physical therapy component will involve exercises to improve flexibility and strength, as well as manual therapy techniques to reduce pain and inflammation. The acupuncture component will involve the insertion of needles into specific points on the body to stimulate the release of endorphins, which are natural painkillers. The study will last for 12 weeks, and participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: the treatment group or the control group. The treatment group will receive the new treatment, while the control group will receive standard care. Both groups will be asked to complete questionnaires at the beginning and end of the study to assess their pain levels and quality of life. The questionnaires will include the Oswestry Disability Index, the Visual Analog Scale, and the Short Form-36 Health Survey. The results of the study will be used to determine whether the new treatment is more effective than standard care in treating low back pain.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized Controlled Trial of a Novel Treatment for Chronic Low Back Pain

Conditions
-----------------
Low Back Pain

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of a 10‐minute rest period on the duration of the second stage of labor. Methods: This was a randomized controlled trial conducted at a university hospital in Korea. A total of 100 women who were in the second stage of labor were randomly assigned to either the rest group (n = 50) or the control group (n = 50). The rest group was instructed to rest for 10 minutes, while the control group was not. The primary outcome was the duration of the second stage of labor. Secondary outcomes included the incidence of perineal lacerations, the use of oxytocin, and the incidence of postpartum hemorrhage. Results: The mean duration of the second stage of labor was significantly shorter in the rest group than in the control group (10.1 ± 3.9 minutes vs. 12.3 ± 4.9 minutes, p = 0.001). The incidence of perineal lacerations was also significantly lower in the rest group than in the control group (12% vs. 24%, p = 0.04). There was no significant difference in the use of oxytocin or the incidence of postpartum hemorrhage between the two groups. Conclusion: A 10‐minute rest period during the second stage of labor may be beneficial in reducing the duration of the second stage of labor and the incidence of perineal lacerations.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the effectiveness of a 12-week Unified Protocol (UP) intervention in reducing depression and anxiety in individuals with Multiple Sclerosis (MS). The UP is a cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) intervention that focuses on teaching individuals skills to manage their emotions and improve their overall well-being. The study will also examine the impact of the UP on other outcomes such as fatigue, sleep quality, pain, self-efficacy, resilience, coping, benefit-finding, quality of life, and flourishing.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic, autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system. It is characterized by inflammation and damage to the myelin sheath, which protects the nerves in the brain and spinal cord. This damage can lead to a range of symptoms, including fatigue, pain, and cognitive impairment. Depression and anxiety are also common in individuals with MS, with up to 50% of individuals experiencing these conditions. These mental health disorders can significantly impact an individual's quality of life and ability to manage their MS symptoms. The Unified Protocol (UP) is a cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) intervention that has been shown to be effective in reducing depression and anxiety in a variety of populations. The UP focuses on teaching individuals skills to manage their emotions and improve their overall well-being. The UP has been adapted for individuals with MS and has shown promising results in reducing depression and anxiety in this population. The purpose of this study is to determine the effectiveness of the UP in reducing depression and anxiety in individuals with MS. The study will also examine the impact of the UP on other outcomes such as fatigue, sleep quality, pain, self-efficacy, resilience, coping, benefit-finding, quality of life, and flourishing. The study will be a randomized controlled trial, with participants randomly assigned to either the UP intervention group or a waitlist control group. The UP intervention will consist of 12 weekly sessions, each lasting approximately 90 minutes. The secondary outcome measures include the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) - Change in Fatigue, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) - Change in Sleep, MOS Pain Effects Scale (PES) - Change in Pain, General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) - Change in Self-efficacy, University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale - Change in MS specific self-efficacy, University of Washington Resilience Scale - Change in Resilience, COPE inventory - Change in Coping, Benefit Finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) - Change in Benefit-finding, Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) - Changes in Quality of Life, Flourishing Scale (FS) - Change in Quality of Life, and Ryff Psychological Well-being Scales (RYFFPWB) - Changes in well-being.

Of course! The Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) measures the level of fatigue in individuals with MS. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) assesses the quality of sleep. The MOS Pain Effects Scale (PES) measures the level of pain experienced. The General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) assesses self-efficacy, while the University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale focuses specifically on MS-specific self-efficacy. The University of Washington Resilience Scale measures resilience. The COPE inventory assesses coping strategies. The Benefit Finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) measures positive coping. The Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) measures quality of life and satisfaction. The Flourishing Scale (FS) also measures quality of life. Lastly, the Ryff Psychological Well-being Scales (RYFFPWB) assess psychological well-being.

The assessments for the secondary outcome measures will also be conducted at baseline, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks. This allows for an evaluation of changes over time and the effectiveness of the Unified Protocol intervention on various aspects of well-being in individuals with MS.
